summary: Since India and Pakistan became separate nations in 1947 , India and Pakistan have fought two wars over Kashmir , the Himalayan province which was split between India and Pakistan . Kashmir , the Himalayan province which was split between them is India only majority Islam province , and an Islam insurgency began on the Indian side in 1989 . More than 45,000 people were killed . A bilateral cease fire was pronounced in 2003 , and Prime Minister Singh of India reduced troop levels by 40,000 in a force of 500,000 . Peace talks began in 2004 and in March 2005 , bus service between India and Pakistan began , the first tangible result of Peace talks . During November 2004 , Prime Minister Singh of India reduced troops on the Kashmir , the Himalayan province which was split between them border as a goodwill gesture prior to Prime Minister Singh of India visit . While there , Prime Minister Singh of India met with Kashmiri separatist leaders . India rejected a Pakistani suggestion that some Kashmir , the Himalayan province which was split between them areas be made independent , placed under joint control , or put under UN administration . The Indian and Pakistani prime ministers were to meet in New Delhi to further the peace process begun in January and facilitated by A bilateral cease fire . Consequently , on April 7 , 2005 , limited bi - weekly bus service between the Indian- and Pakistani - controlled sections of Kashmir , the Himalayan province which was split between them resumed for the first time in 57 years . A border ceasefire begun November 25 , 2003 has held . The US pressured Pakistan to control militant groups . India early 2004 talks with Kashmiri separatists showed little progress . India and Pakistan were to start formal talks on Kashmir , the Himalayan province which was split between them in December . Pakistani President Musharraf suggested making Kashmir , the Himalayan province which was split between them autonomous or putting parts under joint India / Pakistan or UN control . Prime Minister Singh of India committed to making peace with Pakistan but rejected redrawing the Kashmir border . India withdrew some border troops . Prime Minister Singh of India visited Kashmir , the Himalayan province which was split between them three times and announced a Kashmiri economic development plan . Bus service between the Indian- and Pakistani - controlled sections of Kashmir started in April 2005 . There appears to be progress in the Indian - Pakistani dispute over Kashmir , the Himalayan province which was split between them . A bilateral cease fire has held for a year . Prime Minister Singh of India met with Kashmiri political leaders for the first time . India has reduced the number of border troops and announced a multibillion - dollar development plan . Bus service has been opened for the first time in 57 years . The Pakistani President has suggested three solutions : Some areas of Kashmir , the Himalayan province which was split between them could be made independent or placed under joint Indian - Pakistani control or put under UN administration . However , India has ruled out division along religious lines or redrawing international borders .

summary: Pakistan 's President Musharraf and India 's Prime Minister Singh met for talks in New Delhi in April 2005 . Pakistan 's President Musharraf pronounced the peace process , begun in January 2004 , as & quot;irreversible.&quot ; India 's and Pakistan 's agreed to open bank branches in India 's countries . Trade rose to $ 600 million in 2005 , and India and Pakistan pledged improvement in air and shipping services . India and Pakistan also agreed to notify India 's in advance of ballistic missile tests . India 's Prime Minister Singh invited Kashmir 's separatists for peace talks , a critical move toward pushing forward the peace process , begun in January 2004 , . Kashmir 's separatists had previously been excluded from the talks between India and Pakistan . Despite improved economic and cultural relations , India and Pakistan have made little progress on the problem of Kashmir 's . However , leaders of India and Pakistan remain committed to the peace process , begun in January 2004 , . leaders of both countries planned formal talks on the problem of Kashmir in New Delhi on April 17 , leaders of both countries first since India 's Prime Minister Singh took office last May. On April 16 , moderate Kashmiri separatist leaders were to meet with Pakistan 's President Musharraf in New Delhi . In June , moderate Kashmiri separatist leaders made a historic trip to Pakistan 's and met with Pakistani government officials . India 's Prime Minister Singh invited moderate Kashmiri separatist leaders for peace talks to be held on September 5 . In April 2005 Pakistan 's President Musharraf came to New Delhi for an India 's - Pakistan 's cricket match and Pakistan 's President Musharraf first talks with India 's Prime Minister Singh . Kashmiri moderates in the All Party Hurriyat Conference ( APHC ) met with Pakistan 's President Musharraf there and later visited Pakistan 's . Kashmiri moderates in the All Party Hurriyat Conference ( APHC ) demand inclusion in the peace process , begun in January 2004 , . Indian mediators had been in contact with the All Party Hurriyat Conference ( APHC ) leaders since their 2004 talks . Some Kashmiri activists in Indian jails have been freed . India 's Prime Minister Singh invited the All Party Hurriyat Conference ( APHC ) moderates for peace talks September 5th . Pakistan 's President Musharraf and India 's Prime Minister Singh met September 14th in NY , vowed to pursue peace in Kashmir 's but produced no major initiatives . India 's - Pakistan ties have strengthened in other areas . Progress continues to be made in the problem of Kashmir despite the April 2005 killing by suspected Muslim rebels of six Indians , including three policemen . Pakistan 's President Musharraf visited India 's in April 2005 for Pakistan 's President Musharraf first formal talks with the Indian Prime Minister . In June eight moderate separatist leaders from India 's visited Pakistan 's . In September the Indian Prime Minister invited separatists for peace talks . On the economic front , India and Pakistan were scheduled to hold joint economic meetings for the first time in 16 years . India and Pakistan are focusing on banking , air and shipping services , customs rules , and regular bus service .

summary: The FDA has approved the use of an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill . When used within 72 hours after intercourse , an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill prevents pregnancy . Barr Pharmaceuticals proposed that The FDA allow girls age 16 or older to obtain an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill over the counter . Proponents claimed an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill would be invaluable in preventing unplanned pregnancies . Opponents argued that an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill causes abortion , which Opponents strongly oppose . Medical authorities disputed causes . Conservatives feared an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill use would make young girls more promiscuous . Research following 2,000 California girls found that those who used an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill were not more likely to have unprotected sex . Introduction of the & quot;morning - after pill&quot ; led to much controversy over an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill use and distribution . Some groups considered an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill a form of abortion while others argued an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill was not . Some said an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill encouraged teen - age sex while scientific studies indicated an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill did not . an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill was available by prescription only . Proponents argued for an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill sale & quot;over the counter&quot ; ( OTC ) . Opponents said its sale & quot;over the counter&quot ; ( OTC ) would encourage teen - age sex . The FDA rejected a proposal for OTC sales in May 2004 . In January 2005 The FDA continued to consider OTC sales to women 16 years or older . Debate continues on over - the - counter availability of the & quot;morning after pill.&quot ; US supporters consider an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill safe and effective in preventing unwanted pregnancies . Those opposed , especially the Bush administration and the religious right , consider an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill an abortion , interference with & quot;natural law&quot ; , and promoting promiscuity . Two studies found an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill did not increase sexual activity , but also did not decrease pregnancies . The FDA is expected to decide soon whether an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill can be dispensed over the counter to those 16 and older . Also debated is whether pharmacists may refuse to fill prescriptions for an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill . Other nations are also concerned . The conflict over approval of an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill continues . Both sides consider an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill safe and effective . Opponents claim that such accessability would encourage teens to have sex . Supporters say that such accessability would reduce the number of teenage pregnancies significantly . the Bush administration has promoted abstinence - only education and a top The FDA official rejected nonprescription sales , overruling the strong recommendation of The FDA scientific advisers . Six states allow nonprescription sales of an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill . Now there is a proposal that to make an emergency contraceptive , called the morning - after pill available without prescription to those 16 and older , but to require younger teens to consult a physician .

summary: In 2003 , two expert panels at the FDA recommended that Plan B , the morning - after pill , be available over - the - counter . In 2005 , the FDA still had not issued a ruling . In a Congressional hearing , Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wondered if was & quot;a dangerous slide into political opinion as opposed to scientific evidence.&quot ; In the absence of federal action , six states have allowed pharmacists to dispense Plan B , the morning - after pill , without a prescription . The religious right led the effort , nationally and in at least 11 states , to give protection to pharmacists who refuse to fill prescriptions for Plan B , the morning - after pill , because of religious beliefs . the FDA was supposed to make a decision on the revised OTC proposal in January 2005 , but the FDA did not . In February the acting the FDA Commissioner was nominated to be Commissioner . the acting FDA Commissioner declared the subject of the pill & quot;complex&quot ; and could not say when a decision would be made . Some senators refused to vote for confirmation until a decision was announced . As the FDA stalled , debate continued and states began to debate local action and such peripheral issues as whether pharmacists are compelled to sell products to which pharmacists have moral objections . On March 31 , 2005 , Senate Democrats questioned the acting FDA Commissioner on the lack of a decision on over - the - counter ( OTC ) sales of the pill . the acting FDA Commissioner called the delay complex . six states already allow OTC sales , with politicians in other states campaigning on over - the - counter ( OTC ) sales of the morning - after pill , recommended by his staff and available with a prescription since the 1990 's . Discussions are heating up over pharmacists refusing to dispense the pill , even with a prescription . Four states have laws giving pharmacists that right and 11 states are considering laws giving them that right . One pharmacist is suing the Governor of Illinois for that right . Several Democratic senators including Kennedy , Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton , Mikulski , and Murray wanted to delay confirmation of President Bush 's nominee to head the FDA until a decision was made on whether the pill could be sold without prescription . Some pharmacists around the country were refusing to fill prescriptions for any birth control pills , claiming that any birth control pills violate Some pharmacists around the country beliefs . At least eleven states allow pharmacists to refuse to fill prescriptions for religious reasons . Massachusetts may join six other states in allowing the pill to be sold without a prescription and four states are considering laws requiring pharmacists to fill all prescriptions .

summary: With rising prices of natural gas and oil , interest is increasing in alternative fuels . The market for solar power is expected by some to grow 35 % a year in the next five years . Earlier , $ 20,000 , the minimum cost to install a home solar - power system , was too high ; but now higher efficiency and tax and rebate incentives from government and utilities help reduce $ 20,000 , the minimum cost to install a home solar - power system , . California has many solar electricity systems already in operation . Interest is widespread . Portugal plans the world 's biggest solar energy power station . Taiwan claims the best silicon solar cell plant . Italy has Europe 's first solar - powered train . Spain loaned the Philippines $ 4.4 million for a solar project to provide electricity to nearly 300 thousand rural households , schools , potable water systems , and health centers . Portugal planned to begin work on the world 's biggest solar energy power station in 2006 . the world 's biggest solar energy power station was expected to create 240 jobs . The California counties of Fresno and Madera operate 500 solar electricity systems and Long Island powers 560 homes and businesses by solar energy . Italy developed a solar power train that powers air conditioning , illumination , and safety systems . Japan and Wales use solar panels for a portion of train power . Interest in solar power is increasing with large scale projects planned in Portugal and the Philippines . Large energy giants like BP and Royal Dutch Shell are involved in producing equipment . The agricultural valleys of California are considered favorable for solar power . Home conversions to solar power will probably require subsidies to offset initial costs but will lead to low monthly bills . Improvements in semiconductors will aid solar development . Solar panels on trains in Italy and Japan provide for air conditioning , illumination and safety systems . Solar cars and backpacks have been developed . Expectations are high for the growth of solar power . Petroleum industry officials warn solar could become competitive by 2015 . In the US , the solar market is expected to grow by 35 % a year . In California , production increased from 10 megawatts in 2001 to 100 in 2005 . In New York , demand for home systems skyrocketed this year . Portugal is planning a 62 megawatt power station for completion in 2009 . In the Philippines , a $ 63.1 million project is bringing power to rural areas . Taiwan is developing the solar industry chain . Other projects include solar powered trains , cars , and backpack battery chargers .

summary: Germany is the world 's leading solar energy market . Farmers are replacing crops with fields of solar energy panels , thanks to government incentives , which have spurred 150 percent growth in one year . A world leader in renewal energy a decade ago , the U.S. is lagging . For lack of government support , the U.S. share of photovoltaic cell production has dropped from 45 percent in 1996 to 8 percent in 2005 . the U.S. may gain ground by use of technology . One producer predicts that , thanks to technical improvement , the cost of solar systems will drop by two - thirds over the next five years . Italy helped Beijing build a solar energy system for the Olympic Games in 2008 and beyond . China plans to spend $ 180 billion on renewable energy , including substantial solar heat development . Indonesia plans to build thousands of small solar power units to boost power capacity . Taiwan 's renewable energy promotion has yielded the world 's third highest installation density of solar water heaters . Angola developed a plan to supply energy to Angola rural population . a plan to supply energy to its rural population would provide 1300 villages with 15 solar generating plants each . Portugal now has an operating license for the world 's largest solar power station . Indonesia plans thousands of small - scale solar plants to assist remote areas and Angola has a similar 15 - year plan . Italy will help China in building a solar system for hot water for the Olympic Games . China also has a contract with BP Group to develop solar photovoltaic . Germany is the world 's leading solar energy market . California , the third largest market and will increase subsidies for possibly a million rooftop solar panels over the next eleven years . Greece 's president and prime minister have solar panels on official residences . Although California has the world 's 3rd largest market for solar materials , the U.S. is moving slowly toward solar power . Last year , .00067 % of the U.S. electric power came from solar . Germany has the largest world market . China , building a solar powered Olympic village , is planning to expand collection areas to 300 million cubic meters by 2020 and have the photovoltaic market grow from 20 megawatt hours to 10,000 by 2020 . Taiwan 's is proud of having the worlds 3rd highest density of solar water heaters and has a & quot;solar - powered city&quot ; project underway . Angola plans to provide solar power plants to 1,300 villages .

summary: In 2005 the husband and mother of a federal judge in Oregon were shot to death after a federal judge in Oregon made a ruling unfavorable to the leader of a white supremacist group called Creativity . An Arkansas group , White Revolution , clashed with a crowd in Boston where holocaust survivors were commemorating the liberation of Nazi concentration camps . summary: A neo - Nazi group staged a rally in Toledo in December 2005 . Large numbers of police prevented violence . Two months earlier A neo - Nazi group had caused a riot when A neo - Nazi group announced plans for such a rally . More than 30 people were killed in Australia when mobs of drunken white youths attacked people of Middle Eastern appearance at a beach in Sydney . In Wilmington , N.C. , a state - appointed Race Riot Commission found that in 1898 , violence was part of the successful effort of white supremacists to disenfranchise blacks , some of whom held high public office . An unknown number of black residents were killed . Swedish authorities are investigating a former KKK leader and US politician for racial law violations after a former KKK leader and US politician delivered a speech to a neo - Nazi gathering there . White supremacists are suspected in the killing of a Jewish Defense League activist in a federal prison . Neo - Nazis staged rallied at City Hall in Toledo . To avoid violence , about 700 police were deployed , community leaders promised counterdemonstrations would be peaceful , and rally - related activities were confined to City Hall in Toledo , Ohio grounds . In a Sydney , Australia , thousands of white youths , including white supremacists and neo - Nazis , attacked Middle Eastern - looking beachgoers . Some 2,000 police were deployed to maintain order . At least 22 blacks died in Wilmington , N.C. , when white supremacists rioted in 1898 and attempted to put members in office by force . Authorities investigated whether a former KKK leader and US politician violated racism laws in a speech in Sweden , agitating against an ethic group . A neo - Nazi group staged a rally in Toledo . Hundred of officers stood guard . More than 30 people were injured and 16 were arrested in racial violence in Sydney in December 2005 . racial violence in Sydney Australia began when mobs of drunken white youths attacked people who looked Arabic . Sweden investigated a former KKK leader and US politician for violating Sweden racism laws , punishable by four years in prison , in a speech in Sweden , agitating against an ethic group . Toledo police barricaded counter - demonstrators 75 yards from a neo - Nazi rally to avoid a repeated melee . In Sydney , white youths attacked people of Middle Eastern appearance , sparking nights of revenge attacks by carloads of youth . People blocked roads near the local mosque against attack . Heavy police presence and car stops prevented a repeat . White supremacists spent months organizing an 1898 riot and coup d'etat in Wilmington , N.C. that killed blacks , stemmed blacks political advances , and disfranchised a race .

summary: Europe leads the way in producing energy from wind . It is planned that by 2010 , 22 % of Europe electricity will come from renewal sources . Denmark already receives 18 % of Denmark energy from wind power . Four hundred turbines are to be built in the sea off the coast of Spain . Fishermen claim Four hundred turbines will disturb tuna migration and force Fishermen boats into treacherous waters . A U.S. plan to build 130 turbines in the ocean south of Cape Cod is meeting strong opposition from residents of nearby resorts who say 130 turbines would spoil the view , disrupt fishing and harm birds . The first US offshore wind turbine plan was in Nantucket Sound . Opponents of offshore wind power sought a more comprehensive strategy for wind energy and argued The first US offshore wind turbine plan would spoil vacation area aesthetics , disrupt commercial fishing and harm birds and marine life . One study found The first US offshore wind turbine plan would have little effect on the surrounding air , sea , and animal life or fishing conditions . Another study concluded 130 turbines could alter local weather . Fishermen opposed clusters of windmills on Spain southern shore because clusters of windmills on Spain 's southern shore would disturb tuna migration and necessitate dangerous detours . Proponents of wind turbine generated power consider wind turbine generated power a safe , pollution free , way to reduce dependence on fossil fuels . wind turbine generated power counteracts global warming by reducing greenhouse gases and preserves oil and natural gas resources . Proponents of wind turbine generated power contend there is no harm to the local environment and even attract sightseers . Opponents primarily consider wind farms to be a blight on the landscape that lowers property values , tourism and jobs . Opponents expect off shore farms to disrupt commercial shipping , harm birds and marine life , and impact sport and commercial fishing . Land - based farms are deemed to affect local weather , vegetation and wildlife . Proponents of wind power assert that wind power is a safe , non - polluting , renewable alternative to fossil fuel . Opponents say that the turbines are ugly , disrupt fishing , harm birds and marine wildlife , and affect local weather . Wind power is widely used in Europe , both on land and offshore . Now the first U.S. off - shore wind farm has been proposed for Nantucket Sound . Opponents emphasize the aesthetic impact of the first U.S. off - shore wind farm , while a draft environmental report said that the first U.S. off - shore wind farm would not hinder commercial or sport activities nor would the first U.S. off - shore wind farm kill birds or fish or affect currents , water quality , or noise levels .

summary: In eco - friendly nations , such as Germany and Denmark , wind energy has largely replaced traditional coal , gas , oil and nuclear for power generation . There , wind - powered energy is increasing 15 to 30 percent per year . Big investments in wind power are also being made in Brazil , France , mainland China , Spain , Sweden and Turkey . In 2001 , Texas set a U.S. record by installing more wind power capacity than any other state . But recently , 15 states have surpassed a U.S. record . New York , California and Hawaii have enacted legislation requiring that 20 % of energy companies ' output must come from renewable sources by 2020 . Advocates say a Nantucket wind farm could produce three fourths of electricity needs for the Cape Cod area . Wind farms can reduce reliance on fossil fuel , global warming , and , pollution . a Nantucket wind farm could bring jobs , fish and perhaps a tourist attraction . Opponents argue that Nantucket is the wrong place for a farm . The plan relies on unproved technology . A large wind turbine project is planned in Taiwan . A proposed wind farm overlooking Ireland 's oldest religious site was ruled out for fear A proposed wind farm overlooking Ireland 's oldest religious site would disrupt Ireland 's oldest religious site tranquility . Wind power proponents believe the technology will become competitive as the cost of fossil fuel rises and larger turbines are brought online . Turbines are touted for Turbines low noise and the lack of exhaust gas or water . Two negatives with wind power are wind power dependence on the changeable weather and the distances of farms from population centers . Opposition to wind power becomes more ferocious when planned farms are believed to infringe on the vistas of the wealthy and political influential or on historical , religious sites . Advocates for a Nantucket wind farm maintain that a Nantucket wind farm would bring jobs to the Cape Cod area , that a Nantucket wind farm might be a tourist attraction , and that the towers would attract fish . Opponents say that a Nantucket wind farm relies on unproven technology and that Nantucket is the wrong location . A German group building a project in Taiwan claims that a project will cause no pollution , low noise , and no exhaust gas or waste water - a project is clean , competitive , and inexhaustible . In Ireland 's a project near Ireland 's oldest religious site was abandoned because a project near a very old pilgrimage site would & quot;interfere with Ireland 's oldest religious site tranquility.&quot ;

summary: In January 2005 , rescue workers in southern California used snowplows , snowcats and snowmobiles to free people from a highway where snow , sleet , rain and fog caused a 200 - vehicle logjam . A fourth day of storms took a heavy toll as saturated hillsides gave way , mudslides inundating houses and closing highways . People fled neighborhoods up and down the coast . Eight of nine horse races at Santa Anita were canceled for the first time in 10 years . More than 6,000 houses were without power in Los Angeles . A scientist said Los Angeles had not seen such intensity of winter downpours since 1889 - 90 . southern California was drenched by rainstorms in January 2005 . Los Angeles had 15 inches in the first nine days . rainstorms caused severe flooding , sinkholes and mudslides resulting in huge property losses , blocked roads , power outages , hundreds of auto accidents , interruptions of rail traffic , and , by Jan. 10th , twenty deaths . Heroic efforts by hundreds of overtaxed rescue workers saved thousands from collapsed houses , mud piles and floodwaters . Sensitive listening devices and cadaver dogs searched for signs of life in mountains of mud and debris . By Jan 12th good weather was forecast for later in the week . Record - breaking rains brought danger and destruction to southern California in the first weeks of 2005 . The early January 2005 storms dropped more rain in Los Angeles than Los Angeles average annual amount . Several thousand residents endured power outages . Conditions necessitated widespread evacuations . Landslides , mudslides , floods and downed trees caused massive destruction of homes and roads . Stranded motorists required rescue by overtaxed emergency workers . Schools , businesses , rail lines and roads were closed . Beaches were closed for sewage leaks . The number of traffic accidents tripled from the previous dry weekend . In all , The early January storms caused at least 20 deaths and dozens of injuries . southern California was been drenched by storms beginning in late December 2004 , the heaviest drenching in nearly 40 years . Over 15 inches fell during the first nine days . The storm resulted in human deaths and injuries . The storm created flooding , mudslides , and rockslides which caused power outages , evacuations , and disruption of rail services . Beaches , state parks and some mountain and ski resorts were closed . The National Weather Service said flooding , mudslides , and rockslides which caused power outages , evacuations , and disruption of rail services occurs only every 5 - 10 years . The extraordinary weather was attributed to a confluence of tropical air from the South Pacific and a cold front from the North .

summary: Southern California was just recovering from the January 2005 storms in February , when another severe winter storm pummeled Southern California for six days . Sodden hillsides collapsed , sending some houses sliding down slopes and mud toppling others . The rains killed nine people , destroyed dozens of houses , flooded roads and airports , and cut power for thousands . When The rains stopped , emergency crews began the cleanup , working to clear 20 major roads and fill thousands of potholes , some the size of cars . Engineers assessed whether houses were still habitable . Some ambulance crews were diverted to work spotting signs of flooding and mudslides . Good weather in Southern California on Jan. 13 , 2005 was accompanied by a massive cleanup effort as crews cleared mud , rubble and debris . It had been the wettest 15 days on record . Countless roads were closed , Amtrak service was disrupted and in La Conchita the entire town of 260 people had been evacuated . February 12 - 23 another rainstorm hit Southern California . Los Angeles had 9.14 inches of rain with a repetition of floods , mudslides , and sinkholes . Six deaths were reported . Los Angeles estimated the cost of the January 2005 storms in February to Los Angeles roads and facilities at $ 52.5 million . Jan. 13 , 2005 , the rain had stopped and cleanup was underway . Many roads had yet to be cleared . The early January storms claimed 28 lives . another severe winter storm pummeled Southern California for six days . Falling trees , mudslides , rockslides , tornadoes , floods , washed out roads and bridges , and sinkholes threatened residents ' safety and homes . At least nine deaths were attributed to another severe winter storm , and dozens of homes were condemned . Over 100 were rendered temporarily uninhabitable . Los Angeles opened Los Angeles Emergency Operations Center to better coordinate Los Angeles storm response . Damage from the January 2005 storms in February could top $ 100 million . In the aftermath of another severe winter storm residents faced traffic gridlock and massive amounts of mud , rubble and debris . The Transportation Department hurried to clear major roads . Fire Department and California Highway Patrol employees worked round the clock . It was critical to reopen roads and highways so that people could get back to work . Caltrans estimated Caltrans spent $ 11 million for immediate repairs and would spend $ 40 million on roads and other public repairs . State officials and farm and insurance groups estimated damage to homes , roads , and farms at over $ 100 million .

smus: South California was recovering when another storm pummeled.
Sodden hillsides collapsed, sending some houses sliding.
9 people were killed and dozens of houses destroyed.
There are potholes, some of them of the size of cars.
Engineers assessed whether houses could be inhabitable.
Ambulance crews were diverted to work.
Ambulance crews were diverted to work spotting signs of mudslides.
There was a massive cleanup effort.
Los Angeles' roads were costed by January storms.
The rain has stopped and the clean up is underway.
In 2005 the rain stopped and the clean-up was underway.
Many roads had yet to be cleared.
A winter storm pummeled Southern California.
At least 9 deaths were attributed to another storm.
Los Angeles opened the Los Angeles Emergency Operations Center.
Los Angeles opened the Los Angeles Emergency Operations Center to coordinate storm response.
Residents faced the aftermath of another storm.
The Transportation Department hurried to clear major roads.
Employees of California Highway Patrol worked.
Fire Department employees worked round the clock.
It is critical to reopen roads.
Reopen roads so people can get back to work.

summary: John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , served as Deputy Assistant Attorney General , Office of Legal Counsel 2001 - 2003 . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , drafted memos concerning the President 's authority to wage preemptive war , the Geneva Convention , and torture . A Sept. 25 , 2001 secret memo argued that the President 's had authority to wage preemptive war to protect the United Sates without Congressional approval . Other memos redefined torture and advised the President 's that the Geneva Convention does not apply to al - Qaida and the Taliban . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , is also a regular contributor to opinion pages of major newspapers . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , is a constitutional scholar and law professor at the University of California , Berkeley . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , is a prolific writer and a regular contributor to opinion pages of major newspapers . As a Justice Department lawyer from 2001 to 2003 , John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , helped write a series of controversial memos to the White House following the 9/11 attacks . A Sept. 25 , 2001 secret memo concluded that the President 's has the authority to wage preemptive war . Another advised that the Geneva Convention does not apply to al - Qaida and the Taliban non - state terror organizations . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , believes the United Sates should not divulge which interrogation methods short of torture the United Sates might use with terror suspects . As deputy assistant attorney general with Office of Legal Counsel in 2001 , John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , wrote A Sept. 25 , 2001 secret memo concluding the President 's had authority to wage preemptive war against terrorists and countries even if not linked to 9/11 attacks . In 2002 John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , wrote much of A Sept. 25 , 2001 secret memo saying the Geneva Convention did not apply to al - Qaida . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , said rules of war have changed because the enemy has changed . Our leaders can decide what system to apply . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , denied that the White House influenced OLC advice . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , returned to teaching law at the University of California , Berkeley after leaving government . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , helped write a series of legal memos stating that there were no limits on the President 's power to wage war and redefining torture , saying that the Geneva Convention does not apply to the treatment of terrorists . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , asserted that a series of controversial memos would not convert to orders for soldiers to violate human rights . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , insisted that the White House had not dictated or influenced the content of a series of controversial memos . John C. Yoo , a law professor at the University of California , Berkeley , believed that interrogation methods should not be disclosed because terrorists could then train people to resist interrogation methods .

summary: Although John Yoo is best known for John Yoo 2001 - 2003 Justice Dept . memos , John Yoo has actively expressed John Yoo views in later years . John Yoo offered John Yoo opinion on the nominations of Supreme Court Justices . John Yoo urged the U.S. to be more ruthless and cunning in the fight against terrorism setting up fake terrorist organizations that would make fake attacks and compete with al - Qaida for recruits . John Yoo contends that the U.S. has the right to hold & quot;enemy combatants&quot ; indefinitely without charges or lawyers and that the President has the power to unilaterally start a war and overrule the Geneva Convention . John Yoo recommends the U.S. develop new , ruthless and cunning ways to combat terrorist networks , some of which might run afoul of existing laws . In John Yoo new book , John Yoo contends the U.S. has the right to hold enemy combatants indefinitely without charges . John Yoo believes the constitution gives the President sole power to interpret international law . John Yoo believes cruel , inhumane or degrading interrogation techniques fall short of torture and should be employed at the President discretion with prisoners overseas . John Yoo wrote commentary on Supreme Court nominees John Roberts , Harriet Myers and Samuel Alito and on suggested government disaster response improvements . John Yoo helped draft the Patriot Act and a memo narrowly defining torture , and wrote & quot;The Powers of War and Peace&quot ; . John Yoo thinks the U.S. should be ruthless in disrupting terrorist networks , perhaps setting up false terrorist organizations to sow confusion . John Yoo opposes banning secret prisons and harsh interrogations . John Yoo advocates extraordinary presidential powers , including making war and interpreting laws . John Yoo says John Roberts takes a traditional approach to the law , arguing facts instead of pushing big new theories . John Roberts seeks to put biases and feelings aside but does n't claim John Roberts can or should . John Yoo defines torture as intense & quot;pain accompanying serious physical injury , such as organ failure , impairment of bodily function , or even death.&quot ; John Yoo claims that & quot;cruel , inhumane , and degrading treatment&quot ; is something worse than torture . John Yoo thinks the U.S. should be more aggressive in fighting terrorism and find new ways to destroy networks , even assassinating leaders , setting up fake terrorist organizations and deceptive websites , and fabricating attacks on the U.S. John Yoo thinks that a judge should argue the facts of a judge case , not push for new theories and that courts should not make policy on important social issues .

summary: When King Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev of Nepal seized absolute power on Feb. 1 , 2005 , the United States , Britain , India and the United Nations quickly condemned seized calling for a return to democracy . China announced China respect for the choice of the Nepalese , but later condemned China Maoist rebels . On Feb. 2 the European Union condemned King Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev of Nepal action and called for a & quot;speedy&quot ; return to multi - party democracy . On Feb. 3 Pakistan 's Prime Minister opined that recent developments were Nepal internal matters while Japan voiced concern and urged a return to democracy . the United States faced a policy challenge resulting from the unexpected action of Nepal King Gyanendra in dissolving the government and claiming absolute power . King Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev of Nepal claimed it was necessary to restore peace and democracy in the face of Maoist insurgency . The US , Britain and India who provide aid to Nepal have widely condemned King Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev of Nepal action . the United Nations Secretary General Kofi Annan expressed deep concern and the European Union joined the international condemnation of King Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev of Nepal action . Japan , voiced concern at seized . China called seized & quot;an internal affair&quot ; and Pakistan 's adopted the same approach . King Gyanendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev of Nepal power grab added to the regional sense that Nepal is in a downward spiral . the United States , the United Nations , EU , India and Britain condemned seized as a setback for democracy . the United States and India have made no decision on continuation of military aid The US and India were providing to Nepal in Nepal struggle against rebels . Japan urged peace through dialogue . India wants to minimize links between Nepal and India rebels . PM Singh canceled PM Singh attendance at a summit in Bangladesh , which was postponed in response . Pakistan 's and China remained neutral . Human rights groups condemned both sides . Most countries , including the United States , Britain , India , and Japan , have condemned the unexpected action of Nepal 's King Gyanendra in dissolving the government and claiming absolute power . the United States has not yet decided whether to continue the United States military and development aid . India has not yet commented on the United States military aid but is expected to continue to support Nepal fight against its Maoist rebels . Both the United States and the United Nations condemned seized and called for an immediate return to multi - party democracy . International organizations including Amnesty International have denounced seized . China remained neutral , maintaining that this was an & quot;internal matter.&quot ;

summary: The U.S. underlined The U.S. concern with the situation in Nepal with a statement from the White House on Feb. 7 and recalling of The U.S. ambassador on Feb. 14th . The European Union , India and Norway followed suit , recalling The European Union , India and Norway ambassadors . U.N. human rights experts and the International Federation of Journalists denounced human rights violations in Nepal . Then on Feb. 22 India and Norway suspended military aid to Nepal . In early March Japan extended $ 17.1 million in aid to Nepal while urging a return to democracy and the World Bank announced that the World Bank was freezing aid while assessing the situation . International concerns continue over King Gyanendra 's seizure of power . Nine UN human rights experts expressed deep concern . The U.S. , The European Union , India , and Norway have all recalled The US , The European Union , India , and Norway ambassadors to Nepal . India and Britain have suspended military aid to Nepal . Japan did extend $ 17.1 million in non - military aid to Nepal while urging that freedom guaranteed by the constitution be promptly restored . the World Bank froze release of aid to Nepal while the World Bank assessed protection of human rights there . the International Federation of Journalists said that Nepal media has been & quot;suffocated&quot ; by King Gyanendra 's seizure of power . The US ambassador , recalled to Washington for consultations , urged meaningful political discussions leading to national elections . the International Federation of Journalists reported censorship and a suffocated media in Nepal . India told King Gyanendra 's King Gyanendra 's moves had deepened Nepal crisis . Norway recalled Norway ambassador to protest King Gyanendra 's seizure of power and threatened an aid freeze . India and Britain suspended military aid . The U.S. is considering doing the same . the World Bank froze the release of more aid to Nepal . Japan extended Nepal $ 17.1 million in non - military aid while urging a return to democracy . Tourists have been scared away from Nepal . The U.S. , The European Union , India , and Norway recalled The U.S. , the E.U. , India , and Norway ambassadors to protest King Gyanendra 's seizure of power . On Feb. 7 , Japan , urging a return to democracy , announced 7.1 million dollars of aid to Nepal , but as of March 10th , the World Bank had frozen the release of more aid to Nepal , India and Britain had suspended India and Britain military aid , and The U.S. and Norway were considering similar action . Nine U.N. human rights experts have expressed deep concern over King Gyanendra 's actions and the International Federation of Journalists has asserted that Nepal 's media have been & quot;suffocated.&quot ;

summary: The 1998 Good Friday peace accord was suspended in 2002 due to violent activity by the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) . An appeal in April 2005 by Sinn Fein leader Adams to the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) to abandon armed struggle was endorsed in May by Irish Prime Minister Ahern . All interested parties awaited a response from the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) . In late June the U.S. State Department supported British Prime Minister Blair 's and Ahern 's call for a response . In late July there was a first glimmer of hope as three senior Sinn Fein leaders resigned from the ruling body of the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) military wing . Irish Prime Minister Ahern said the main goal of The 1998 Good Friday peace accord , a joint Catholic - Protestant administration in Northern Ireland , could be revived only with a complete end of the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) weapons use . The 1998 Good Friday peace accord led to a virtual end of violence in Northern Ireland . Sinn Fein leader Adams has appealed to the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) members to end IRA members armed struggle in favor of democratic politics . Hopes are rising in Northern Ireland that the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) will disarm . British Prime Minister Blair 's and Ahern 's will chair a review of the Northern Ireland situation in London . The 1998 Good Friday peace accord ended three decades of violence and created a power - sharing plan in Northern Ireland . The 1998 Good Friday peace accord required a complete end to the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) paramilitarism and criminality , and decommissioning of the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) weapons . Power - sharing collapsed in 2002 following continued the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) underground activities . In 2005 Sinn Fein leader Adams appealed to the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) members to give up violence in favor of democratic methods , followed by similar appeals by Irish Prime Minister Ahern and Protestant party leader Ian Paisley . Sinn Fein leader Adams , Martin McGuinness and Martin Ferris resigned from the the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) paramilitary council , severing the IRA paramilitary council political and military wings . The 1998 Good Friday peace accord had proposed a joint Catholic - Protestant administration , including Sinn Fein , for Northern Ireland . Although ending decades of fighting , power sharing collapsed in 2002 because of the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) activities and failure to disarm . In 2005 , British and Irish leaders sought to restore the power sharing institutions . Protestants insisted the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) disband and disarm . Protestant leaders was urged to come onboard the peace process . On August 23 , three Sinn Fein leaders resigned from leadership positions in the Irish Republican Army ( IRA ) , severing three Sinn Fein leaders military ties .

summary: On July 26 Ireland 's deputy prime minister predicted news of a response from the IRA later in the week . The next day senior figures in Sinn Fein departed for the U.S. signaling a forthcoming announcement . An Irish government spokesman warned that an the IRA commitment to non - violence had to be backed by an unambiguous process for disposing of all of the IRA weapons . On July 29 the long - awaited statement arrived declaring that & quot;All the IRA units have been ordered to dump arms.&quot ; U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan hailed the long - awaited statement while British Prime Minister Blair called the long - awaited statement a & quot;very positive&quot ; statement . the IRA has reportedly renounced the IRA armed struggle for a united Ireland . The disposal of the IRA arms remains unclear . Adams did confirm that the IRA was on the verge of making a significant statement . Ahern remained cautious and Northern Ireland Protestant leader Ian Paisley requires absolute proof . U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan hailed renounced and British Prime Minister Blair called the long - awaited statement very positive . The the IRA pledge to lay down the IRA arms and adopt peaceful means to end British rule in Northern Ireland took effect at 4:00 PM on July 28 . American businessman Niall O'Dowd brokered the IRA - US talks leading to a 1994 cease - fire . The 1998 accord established Northern Ireland local government . In December 2004 Sinn Fein rejected Protestant demands that the IRA arms destruction be photographed , halting political progress . Following Adams April 2005 appeal to lay down arms the IRA consulted with members . Sinn Fein leaders visited the U.S. but entry was denied to fugitive Rita O'Hare . In July the IRA declared an end to violence . the IRA ordered quot;All IRA units to dump arms , inviting Protestant and Catholic clergymen to serve as witnesses . the IRA refused to disband as Protestants demanded . In late August , the IRA ordered an end to the IRA armed campaign in Northern Ireland , declaring there is an alternate way to achieve a united Ireland , free from British rule . If The IRA pledge to lay down its arms and adopt peaceful means to end British rule in Northern Ireland holds , it will be a historic turning point in the violent history of Ireland 's and Northern Ireland . The majority Protestant party is expected to demand a one year delay in power sharing . Other remaining questions are will the IRA end criminal operations , will the Catholics support the new police , and will the promised destruction of the massive the IRA weapons stash occur . World leaders praised ordered .

summary: In October 2004 , Sri Lanka 's Tamil Tiger rebel group blamed Sri Lanka 's for delay in reviving negotiations to end the conflict that had claimed 60,000 lives since 1972 . Sri Lanka 's Tamil Tiger rebel group suspended talks in April 2003 when internecine struggles broke out between rebel groups . Sri Lanka 's claims Sri Lanka 's Tamil Tiger rebel group are holding up negotiations and accuses Sri Lanka 's Tamil Tiger rebel group of killing over 250 of Sri Lanka 's Tamil Tiger rebel group political rivals since the truce of 2002 went into effect . Sri Lanka 's released ten Tamil Tigers from jail on bail , and Sri Lanka 's Tamil Tiger rebel group responded by freeing two homeguards who had been held hostage since August . Negotiations under the Norwegian - sponsored peace process of February 2002 between The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam ( LTTE ) and Sri Lanka 's were at a standstill in October 2004 due in part to internecine struggles within The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam ( LTTE ) . The main LTTE in northern Sri Lanka was challenged by a faction in the east with a leader known as Karuma who broke ranks in March 2004 . While The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam ( LTTE ) sought support in Europe and Japan offered help in resumption of negotiations , Sri Lanka 's blamed The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam ( LTTE ) for breakdown of the peace process which has been stalled since April 2003 . A group from The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam ( LTTE ) met in Switzerland to prepare for talks with Sri Lanka 's . A cease in Switzerland brokered by Norwegian - sponsored has been observed since February 2002 ; however , internecine clashes between The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam ( LTTE ) and rival groups counter efforts to revive negotiations between The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam ( LTTE ) and the government of Sri Lanka . Sri Lanka 's has sent counterproposals to the Interim Self Government to those put forward by The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam ( LTTE ) . Violence continues and a Swiss national was killed . Japanese envoy Akashi was to arrive in Sri Lanka 's to push for resumption of talks . Efforts to revive talks between The Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam ( LTTE ) and the government of Sri Lanka have been stalled by persistent clashes between rival rebel groups and by continued killings . In early October the top rebel group was in Switzerland to prepare for the next round of talks , while Sri Lanka 's said that Sri Lanka 's had finalized a set of counter proposals for the resumption of direct negotiations . Japan special envoy arrived in Sri Lanka 's on 27 October for a 7 - day visit to encourage an early resumption of peace talks . Japan is optimistic and has promised continued assistance for Japan reconstruction .

summary: Japanese and Norwegian diplomats visited Sri Lanka in October 2004 in an effort to persuade Sri Lanka and Tamil Tiger rebels to resume negotiations toward an end to hostilities . Tamil Tiger rebels insisted Tamil Tiger rebels had not given up Tamil Tiger rebels right to secede , although Tamil Tiger rebels agreed to explore federal solutions . Increasing violence preceding the visit of the Norwegian foreign minister forced Sri Lanka to heighten security measures . Tamil Tiger rebels blamed Increasing violence preceding the visit of the Norwegian foreign minister on elements who wanted to discredit Tamil Tiger rebels . In November , Sri Lanka accused Tamil Tiger rebels of breaking a Norwegian - arranged ceasefire by killing a government soldier and a military informant . A special Japanese envoy met with Sri Lanka 27 - 30 Oct. and on Nov. 1 left for the north for talks with LTTE . the Norwegian foreign minister , preceded by violence and increased security , arrived in Colombo on Nov. 9 in a fresh attempt to revive peace talks . the Norwegian foreign minister said the Norwegian foreign minister did not have & quot;high expectations.&quot ; LTTE announced on Nov. 16 that LTTE was prepared to start peace talks on the basis of LTTE proposed Self - Governing Authority . the Norwegian foreign minister lack of & quot;high expectations&quot ; was borne out by outbreaks of violence in eastern Sri Lanka Nov. 17 - 22 . Japanese envoy Akashi ended talks with Sri Lanka and awaits meeting with LTTE leaders hoping to salvage the peace process . Japan is Sri Lanka largest donor and supports the peace process . the peace process was officially blocked over differences on an agenda but diplomats say the split among Tamil Tiger rebels could be the real reason . the government and Tamil Tiger rebels held six rounds of direct negotiations between September 2002 and April 2003 . the Norwegian foreign minister will visit Sri Lanka to try to revive stalled peace talks . the Norwegian foreign minister arrived in Sri Lanka on 10 November to promote the peace process . the Norwegian foreign minister said that the Norwegian foreign minister did not have & quot;high expectations&quot ; but that it was & quot;important to keep engaging with the parties.&quot ; Japan peace envoy met with key government officials and rebel leaders earlier . Tamil Tiger rebels demanded that Sri Lanka and all coalition partners be unified in supporting the peace process and added that Tamil Tiger rebels were ready to resume peace talks if Sri Lanka responded positively to Tamil Tiger rebels proposal for self - rule .

summary: Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , was arrested in 2005 for trying to leave Japan on a revoked U.S. passport . Japan planned to deport Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , to the U.S. , where Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , was wanted for ignoring sanctions against Yugoslavia . deport meant 10 years in jail . Iceland intervened , and Japan agreed not to deport Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , if Iceland would give Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , citizenship . Iceland furnished Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , a special passport and residency permit . Japan insisted on full citizenship , which was finally granted . Iceland revered Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , because Iceland was there that Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , defeated Boris Spassky , the Russian chess champion , in 1972 , during the cold war . Bobby Fischer , held in detention in Japan in March 2005 awaiting deportation to the U.S. , where he was wanted for ignoring sanctions against Yugoslavia , could achieve asylum in Iceland if granted Icelandic citizenship . Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , was given residency status , but Iceland parliament had rejected citizenship in February . Several Icelandic politicians indicated on March 16 that Iceland 's parliament was likely to grant citizenship . A parliamentary committee which reached no decision on March 17 saying they were awaiting more documents from Japan , voted in favor of citizenship on March 18 . On March 21 Iceland 's parliament voted in favor 40 - 0 with two abstentions and 21 absent . Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , has been held in detention in Japan for eight months after trying to leave Tokyo on a revoked U.S. passport . Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , faces deportation and prison in the U.S. , where he was wanted for ignoring sanctions against Yugoslavia for violating sanctions on Yugoslavia by playing there in 1992 . Supporters worked to secure Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , passage to Iceland . Iceland 's parliament granted Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , a foreigner 's passport and a residency permit . But , a foreigner 's passport and a residency permit was not enough . After receiving assurance that Icelandic citizenship would enable Japan to free Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , , Iceland 's parliament granted Icelandic citizenship to Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , . Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , can avoid deportation from Japan to the U.S. , where he was wanted for ignoring sanctions against Yugoslavia if Iceland upgrades Iceland granting residency to full citizenship . Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , is popular in Iceland . Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , faces charges in the U.S. , where he was wanted for ignoring sanctions against Yugoslavia for violating sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia for playing there in 1992 , and possibly for tax evasion . Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , wants to marry the head of Japan chess association . Since leaving the U.S. , where he was wanted for ignoring sanctions against Yugoslavia , Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , has ranted against the US and Jews . Iceland 's parliament has granted citizenship to Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , where Bobby Fischer , the former chess grand master , is expected to reside .

summary: In March , 2005 , when Iceland granted citizenship to Bobby Fischer , allowing Bobby Fischer to escape extradition to the U.S. from a Japanese prison , a Japanese official said there was no reason to hold Bobby Fischer longer . Supporters said Bobby Fischer had lost weight and grown a long beard during Bobby Fischer eight months in prison . U.S. officials prepared to file tax evasion charges against Bobby Fischer . Bobby Fischer had renounced U.S. citizenship , but U.S. officials noted that did not allow citizens to escape prosecution for crimes in the U.S. On March 22 a Japanese official said it was legally possible to send Bobby Fischer to Iceland if Bobby Fischer obtained citizenship . Bobby Fischer lawyer expected Bobby Fischer to be released within the week . citizenship still required the signature of Iceland president . The U.S. State Department expressed disappointment over granted . As of March 23 U.S. officials were preparing tax - evasion charges against Bobby Fischer which might render Bobby Fischer extraditable from Iceland . March 23 Iceland ambassador to Japan said Iceland had forwarded documents to Japan confirming Bobby Fischer Icelandic citizenship and hoped to give Bobby Fischer a passport before the weekend . granted made it legally possible for Japan to deport Bobby Fischer to Iceland . Japanese law only permits deportation to a country where a person is a citizen . Bobby Fischer Icelandic passport was expected to be ready on March 23 . Japanese officials agreed to allow Bobby Fischer to travel to Iceland after Bobby Fischer withdraws Bobby Fischer pending lawsuit against Japan to block Bobby Fischer deportation . A Bobby Fischer supporter said A Fischer supporter would do so on the morning of March 24 on A Fischer supporter way to the airport to fly to Iceland . Japan may allow Bobby Fischer to go to Iceland if Bobby Fischer withdraws his pending lawsuit against the Japanese government to block his deportation . Fischer 's Icelandic citizenship still requires Iceland 's president signature but requires appears assured . Bobby Fischer has been in Japanese prison for six months including time in solitary for a tussle with guards . Bobby Fischer renounced U.S. citizenship but not through proper process so Bobby Fischer remains a US citizen said The U.S. State Department . Bobby Fischer is a fugitive from justice and there is federal warrant for Bobby Fischer arrest . Bobby Fischer alleged violation of US sanctions is not considered extraditable by Japan .

summary: Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq , formed the anti - war group Gold Star Families For Peace in early 2005 . Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq was turned away while trying to protest the Iraq War at the Pentagon and although Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq spoke out across the nation it was Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq roadside vigil near President Bush 's Texas ranch that gained the attention of the nation and the world . Beginning on Aug. 6 , 2005 Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq vowed to maintain her roadside vigil near President Bush 's Texas ranch until President Bush 's spoke with Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq or finished President Bush 's August vacation . By August 11 neither President Bush 's nor Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq had given in . Following Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq son 's April 2004 death in Iraq , Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq has made regular public appearances across the nation protesting the Iraq War . Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq co - founded the anti - war group Gold Star Families For Peace . On August 8 , 2005 , Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq led an antiwar protest down the road leading to President Bush 's ranch near Crawford , Texas . Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq and about 50 antiwar activists established a roadside camp not far from President Bush 's Texas ranch , vowing to remain until President Bush 's met with Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq . Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq used the internet to garner publicity . By August 11 , several dozen protesters from across the nation had joined Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq at Camp Casey , named for her son 's . When her son 's was killed in Iraq Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq launched an anti - war campaign . Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq made public appearances to oppose the Iraq War and founded the anti - war group Gold Star Families For Peace . Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq received support from anti - war groups in Washington and spoke with Democratic Congressmen . Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq traveled to Texas with anti - war activists to seek a meeting with President Bush 's at President Bush 's Texas ranch . Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq was denied a meeting and camped near President Bush 's Texas ranch , saying Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq would remain there until President Bush 's met with Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq . Leading anti - war activists joined Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq protest in Texas and Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq received liberal the internet support . After her son 's died in Iraq , Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq began protesting the Iraq War . Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq founded the anti - war group Gold Star Families For Peace and began making appearances and leading protests around the nation . On Aug. 6 , 2005 , Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq led protestors to Crawford , Texas , demanding to meet with President Bush 's . Two officials met with Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq , but Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq set up her roadside vigil near President Bush 's Texas ranch and swore to continue until President Bush 's personally met with Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq , even if Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq had to go to Washington . This protest drew world - wide media attention and garnered support from other anti - war activists . Cindy Sheehan , whose soldier son was killed in Iraq took This protest to the internet with a conference with bloggers .

summary: By Aug. 13 Sheehan 's group of about a half - dozen activists had grown to about 300 including reporters and confronted by about 100 Bush supporters . The drainage - ditch roadside encampment , dubbed Camp Casey after Sheehan 's son , was crowded and caused traffic congestion . On August 16 Sheehan 's announced that a neighbor had offered a spacious field about one mile from Bush ranch to accommodate The drainage - ditch roadside encampment , dubbed Camp Casey after Sheehan 's son , . Sheehan 's promised to remain encamped there throughout Bush 5 - weeek stay and to return whenever Bush does . Sheehan 's also announced a series of 1,000 candlelight vigils nationwide on Aug. 17 . Over 100 protesters have joined The drainage - ditch roadside encampment , dubbed Camp Casey after Sheehan 's son , . On Aug. 13 , over 350 rallied at The drainage - ditch roadside encampment , dubbed Camp Casey after Sheehan 's son , , undaunted by an earlier counter rally across the road . Sheehan 's vows to remain through Bush 's 5 - weeek stay , unless Bush meets with Sheehan 's . To get Sheehan 's message out , Sheehan 's has received aid from public relations and political operatives and a television spot . As local residents have grown irritated by the stream of protesters , Sheehan 's announced plans to move The drainage - ditch roadside encampment , dubbed Camp Casey after Sheehan 's son , to a spacious field about one mile from Bush 's ranch . They plan to complete move before a dusk candlelight vigil on Aug. 17 . Six days after Sheehan 's arrived in Texas more than 350 protestors , including members of Code Pink and True Majority , and over 100 people supporting Bush had converged on The drainage - ditch roadside encampment , dubbed Camp Casey after Sheehan 's son , . Sheehan 's continued Sheehan 's protests and received support from liberal groups . Sheehan 's announced plans for 1000 candlelight protest vigils nationwide . Sheehan 's stated Sheehan 's would continue Sheehan 's anti - war activities for the duration of Bush 's 5 - weeek stay unless Bush met with Sheehan 's . Sheehan 's was savvy in using the media for Sheehan 's cause . Sheehan 's sought to embarrass Bush as a strategy to advance Sheehan 's political objective . Sheehan 's is receiving more support as Sheehan 's vigil continues . The number of protestors rose to 350 and the Bush contingent reached 250 , creating parking problems and traffic jams . The drainage - ditch roadside encampment , dubbed Camp Casey after Sheehan 's son , included 100 's of white crosses representing those killed in Iraq . Someone knocked over many of 100 's of white crosses representing those killed in Iraq , drawing outrage . On Aug. 17 , protestors began moving to land provided by one of Bush 's neighbors , where protestors will have more parking available . Nearly 1,000 candlelight vigils were planned to occur nationwide that evening . Sheehan 's also is getting public relations advice and is refusing to pay Sheehan 's taxes .

summary: On March 2 , 2005 the Supreme Court faced the issue of whether display of the Ten Commandments ( T.C. ) at government buildings violates the principle of separation of church and state . Two cases from Texas and Kentucky raised several questions . Are the T.C. a religious statement , a part of legal history , or both ? If courts and legislatures can call for God 's help in invocations , what 's wrong with displaying the T.C. ? Does the appearance of the T.C. among other statuary constitute an endorsement ? From justices ' questions and remarks a split decision seemed likely . On March 2 , 2005 , the Supreme Court heard Two cases from Texas and Kentucky . In Texas , a homeless former lawyer challenged the constitutionality of an inscribed monument displayed on state capitol grounds . In Kentucky , the ACLU claimed copies displayed in two courthouses , modified twice before in response to court rulings , still violated the First Amendment because the original purpose was religious and modified were a sham . Supporters argued that the Ten Commandments are a recognized symbol of law , with both secular and religious functions . justices ' will issue an opinion by late June . a homeless former lawyer is challenging the constitutionality of an inscribed monument displayed on state capitol grounds . A Kentucky case involves the constitutionality of the Ten Commandments displays in two courthouses . Opponents of Ten Commandments displays in two county courthouses argue Ten Commandments displays in two county courthouses violate the First Amendments prohibition on establishing an official state religion . Supporters argue the Ten Commandments serve a secular historic function as well as a religious one . The Bush administration has argued on behalf of Ten Commandments displays in two county courthouses . Questioning by justices during hearings suggests they are headed for a split decision . the Supreme Court heard arguments in Two cases from Texas and Kentucky on March 2nd about the conditions under which the government could display the Ten Commandments and whether such displays violated the First Amendment . A Kentucky case concerns an inscribed monument displayed on state capitol grounds . A Kentucky case concerns framed copies of the Ten Commandments which hang with non - religious documents in two courthouses . framed copies of the Ten Commandments which hang with non - religious documents in two county courthouses have been modified twice in response to lower court rulings . Justice O'Connor is expected to cast the swing votes .

summary: On June 27 , 2005 the Supreme Court , in a pair of 5 - 4 rulings , found that the display of the Ten Commandments ( T.C. ) in a park at the Texas State Capitol was proper , but the displays in the County Courthouses in Kentucky were so overtly religious as to be impermissible . a pair of 5 - 4 rulings made it clear that such disputes must be decided case by case with specific facts determining whether there is a violation of the Establishment Clause . Justice Breyer was the swing vote as the only justice voting with the majority in both cases . While hearing arguments , the Supreme Court justices seemed to grapple for a standard which would keep the government from endorsing a religion without eradicating the government historical and cultural ties to religion . On June 27 , the Supreme Court ruled that displaying the Ten Commandments ( T.C. ) on government property does not necessarily violate the constitutional principle of separation between church and state . the Supreme Court ruled that the monument displayed at the Texas State Capitol , one of thousands donated across the government and displayed along with 16 other secular sculptures , was proper . However , the Supreme Court ruled that the courthouse displays in Kentucky were overtly religious and therefore impermissible . the Supreme Court ruled 5 - 4 that the display of the Ten Commandments ( T.C. ) in a park at the Texas State Capitol did not violate constitutional principles . Chief Justice Rehnquist wrote for the Supreme Court and was joined by Justices Scalia , Kennedy , Thomas and Justice Breyer . Justices O'Connor , Stevens , Souter and Ginsburg dissented . In Kentucky , the prevailing opinion was that the displays in the County Courthouses in Kentucky was overtly religious and thus impermissible . Souter wrote the opinion and was joined by Justices Stevens , O'Connor , Ginsburg and Justice Breyer . a pair of 5 - 4 rulings conveyed the message that disputes over religious displays must be decided on a case by case . the Supreme Court made a pair of 5 - 4 rulings , leaving the issue to be decided on a case - by - case basis . Justice Breyer cast the critical swing vote in both cases . the Supreme Court ruled that the display of the Ten Commandments ( T.C. ) in a park at the Texas State Capitol was constitutional because the display of the Ten Commandments ( T.C. ) in a park at the Texas State Capitol was one of 17 monuments , the display of the Ten Commandments ( T.C. ) in a park at the Texas State Capitol had historical as well as religious significance , and the display of the Ten Commandments ( T.C. ) in a park at the Texas State Capitol had been there for over 40 years without challenge . In contrast , in Kentucky the Ten Commandments ( T.C. ) were initially displayed alone ; the accompanying historical documents were added in response to a lawsuit , seemingly to hide a religious motivation .

summary: In the night of October 7 , 2004 , suspected terrorist car bombs ripped through three Egyptian Red Sea resorts popular with vacationing Israelis . At least 30 people were killed and at least 100 were wounded . Last month , Israeli intelligence warned Israelis to keep out of the Sinai desert , citing information about possible attacks . suspected terrorist car bombs came amid a massive Israeli army offensive in the north of the Gaza Strip . The previously unheard of World Islamist Group claimed responsibility for the Taba Hilton Hotel blast , saying the Taba Hilton Hotel blast was in revenge for Palestinians and Arabs killed in Palestine and Iraq . suspected terrorist car bombs rocked three Egyptian Red Sea resorts popular with vacationing Israelis . The largest explosion occurred in Taba Hilton and the other two in nearby villages . suspected terrorist car bombs followed warnings from Israeli Intelligence to keep out of the Sinai desert . It is not clear how many were killed and wounded in suspected terrorist car bombs . Several conflicting casualty numbers were reported . There were no official reports about the cause of suspected terrorist car bombs , but police believe suspected terrorist car bombs were caused by car bombs . The previously unheard of World Islamist Group claimed responsibility for the Taba Hilton Hotel blast but responsibility for the Taba Hilton Hotel blast can not be verified . suspected terrorist car bombs shook three Egyptian Red Sea resorts popular with vacationing Israelis . At least 30 people were killed and 100 wounded . Initially reported as a gas leak , The largest explosion may have been a truck bomb driven into Taba Hilton . the other two took place to the southwest at Ras al - Sultan and Nuweiba . At least seven died at Ras al - Sultan , most Egyptian workers . The previously unheard of World Islamist Group claimed responsibility for the Taba Hilton Hotel blast . Shin Bet intelligence service had advised Israelis not to go Sinai resorts during holidays . In October 7 , 2004 , suspected terrorist car bombs shook three Egyptian Red Sea resorts popular with vacationing Israelis , killing At least 30 people and wounding 125 . A powerful car bomb close to the entrance of Taba Hilton destroyed much of Taba Hilton . Two hours later two vans exploded at tourist camps in Ras Satan ( Ras al - Sultan ) and Nueiba . Seven died at Ras al - Sultan , mostly Egyptian workers . The previously unheard of World Islamist Group claimed responsibility for the Taba Hilton Hotel blast . the Taba Hilton Hotel blast occurred Thursday night at the close of the Jewish holiday of Sukkot , amid an Israeli offensive in the Gaza Strip that left 93 Palestinians dead .
