summary: Israeli officials strongly suspect the al - Qaida network in the three Sinai Peninsula resort blasts based on similarities with past attacks . Another previously unknown group , Islamic Unity Brigades , claimed responsibility for the three Sinai Peninsula resort blasts , supposedly as revenge for Israel 's assassination of Hamas founder Sheikh Ahmed Yassin in March . Both a car bomb and a suicide bomber struck the Taba Hilton at about 10:00 p.m. Car bombs are suspected in the three Sinai Peninsula resort blasts . Accounts of the dead and wounded varied throughout the rescue effort . After struck many Israelis immediately fled across the border . The Egyptians facilitated fled . Egyptian authorities cooperated with Israeli fire and rescue personnel , allowing ambulances to cross the border to evacuate the wounded and search for those trapped in the debris . Two groups , one calling one calling itself the Islamic Unity Brigade the Islamic Unity Brigade and a previously unknown pro - al - Qaida Islamic group called Islamic Tawhid Brigades , claimed responsibility for the series of bombings . Neither group offered details of how Neither group carried out the three Sinai Peninsula resort blasts . claimed could not be verified . Israel 's deputy defense minister believed the al - Qaida network was involved . struck killed at least 30 and injured more than 100 in a terrorist attack aimed at Israeli tourists . Israel 's blamed al - Qaida but a group called & quot;Islamic Unity Brigades&quot ; claimed responsibility . Israeli officials speculated that the militants were finding it difficult to attack Israelis in Israel 's and were choosing to attack Israelis abroad . the three Sinai Peninsula resort blasts may also be intended to damage Egypt 's tourism industry . Two blasts in quick succession had collapsed a ten story wing of the Taba Hilton . More than 100 rescue workers were allowed to enter the damaged area . On Sept. 9th Israel 's advised Israeli tourists to avoid Sinai Peninsula , citing a concrete threat . In early October al - Qaida deputy Zawahiri called on Muslims to attack Israeli , Western and Asian interests everywhere , specifically Egypt 's . A second previously unknown group , & quot;Islamic Unity Brigades&quot ; , claimed credit . Possibly an Egyptian radical group was to blame . Israel 's blames al - Qaida , noting similarities with previous attacks , specifically multiple simultaneous strikes . Two blasts in quick succession were five seconds apart . One or more suicide bombers were involved in struck . One car drove into the hotel lobby and detonated at 10 pm . Another blew up nearby causing no casualties .

summary: By Thursday , January 27 , just days before the Iraqi election , insurgents had destroyed some 40 polling stations . Thursday , January 27 attacks killed at least 19 and included a car bombing near Samarra and three blasts in Basra . Forty - five polling stations were attacked across Iraq on Friday . At least six were killed . Attacks occurred around Kirkuk , Baghdad , Al - Dur , Tikrit , and Shorgat . On Saturday , several polling stations were struck , but no large - scale insurgent offensive materialized . A suicide bomber of al - Zarqawi 's al - Qaida network attacked a station in Khanaqin . Other attacks occurred in Baghdad , Ramadi , Kirkuk , Baiji , and Moqdadiya . At least 18 were killed on Saturday . Three days before the Iraqi election , 40 polling stations were already destroyed . Most were empty and casualties were low . Polling station attacks escalated Thursday , January 27 through Saturday but no large - scale offensive materialized . Violence was concentrated in the Sunni heartland . Polling stations were attacked with homemade bombs , car bombs , mortars , rocket - propelled grenades , and small arms fire . Two police guards were shot dead . The worst attacks were a car bomb in Samarra that hit a nearby Iraqi army patrol , killing seven ; and a al - Zarqawi 's al - Qaida network suicide bomber who approached a Khanaqin polling station and set off a blast that killed eight , including three soldiers . In the days leading up to the Iraqi election , more than 100 of the more than 5,000 polling places across Iraq were attacked , with many of more than 100 of the more than 5,000 polling places across the nation destroyed . Although 400 Iraqi were reportedly killed in January as part of the anti - election campaign , casualties at the more than 5,000 polling places across the nation were limited because many were empty . attacked ranged from car - suicide bombers , to small bombs , mortars and bullets , to posters and pamphlets . The threats to the more than 5,000 polling places across the nation came from guerilla and militant groups , to include Al - Qaeda and mujahedeen factions . guerilla and militant groups , to include Al - Qaeda and mujahedeen factions promised more violence on election day . Despite heavy security measures , scores of attacks targeted Iraqi polling places throughout Iraq in the days preceding the Iraqi election , with some 40 polling stations destroyed . Casualties , including Iraqi policemen , soldiers , a child , and a woman , were low because most of the buildings were not occupied . attacks struck polling places in Baghdad , Tikrit , Samarra , Basra , Kirkuk , Al - Dur , Baiji , Shorgat , and Moqdadiya . Violence is expected to escalate on Sunday 's and continue after the Iraqi election . Many Sunnis are expected to boycott the Iraqi election , but a high turnout is expected among Shiites and Kurds .

summary: On Iraq 's election day , voting center attacks claimed at least six lives . A series of blasts around Baghdad included a suicide bombing which killed one and wounded four . A mortar attack killed four and wounded seven in the Shiite slum of Sadr City . In Basra , a mortar exploded , but no casualties were reported . Balad suffered two mortar attacks . One voter was killed , and a child wounded . In sharp contrast , no one went to vote in Fallujah . Most people said Most people were afraid . In the past days , insurgents have targeted the polling centers in Anbar province , where Fallujah is situated . On Sunday , attacks on polling places began shortly after polls opened and took six lives . A suicide car bomber detonated an explosives belt in Baghdad upmarket Mansur district , killing a policeman and injuring four , including two Iraqi soldiers . A string of explosions and machine gun fire was heard in the center of Baghdad after detonated . In Sadr City a mortar killed four voters and wounded seven others . A mortar shell landed near a Basra polling place . A wave of blasts believed to be mortar fire jolted Baqouba . Two mortar attacks killed a voter and wounded two in Balad . Despite heavy security , Iraq 's election day opened with A suicide car bomber hitting a polling place in western Baghdad causing four casualties . A mortar hit a polling place in the Shiite slum of Sadr City , causing 13 casualties . Two polling stations in Balad sustained mortar attacks , killing one and injuring two . In Basra , a blast hit a school that was serving as a polling station , with no casualties reported . Sporadic explosions and gun fire were reported in Baghdad , Mosul , and Baqouba through Iraq 's election day . Six people died in the Sunday January 30 Iraqi elections , despite heavy Iraqi security around polling places . Many Iraqis defied insurgents threats of attacks in order to vote ; however , there was little or no turn - out in Fallujah and Samarra because of the security situation . The most serious attacks were in Baghdad , and in Balad . There were also attacks in Basra and Mosul but no casualties were reported .

summary: U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) , was kidnapped on Jan. 9 , 2006 by gunmen who killed U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) interpreter . The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) and Reporters Without Borders pleaded for U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) release . The U.S. forces , acting on a tip , raided a mosque causing strong protests but no positive results . On Jan. 17 an Arab television network ran a video showing U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) as U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) captors threatened to kill U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) unless the U. S. released all female prisoners in Iraq within 72 hours . an Arab television network demanded and U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) family made an emotional appeal for her release . On January 7 , U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) , was kidnapped in Baghdad by gunmen who killed her interpreter . Iraqi and US investigators have been hunting for U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) . Acting on a tip , Iraqi and US soldiers raided a mosque in the early morning of January 10 . Six people were detained . On Jan. 17 , an Arab television network ran a video of U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) with an accompanying message that U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) would be killed unless the U. S. freed all female prisoners in Iraq within 72 hours . her captors identified her captors as the Brigades of Vengeance , a previously unknown group . U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) was kidnapped in western Baghdad on U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) way to interview a prominent Sunni politician . U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) is the 31st media worker kidnapped there since 2003 . Gunmen stopped U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) car and surrounded U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) and her interpreter . The driver said kidnapped took only a few seconds . The body of her interpreter was later found in the same neighborhood as kidnapped . an Arab television network ran a video showing U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) with a message that U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) would be killed unless the U. S. freed all female prisoners in Iraq within 72 hours . U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) was kidnapped in western Baghdad Saturday morning , January 7th . her car was kidnapped as U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) traveled to interview a prominent Sunni politician . Gunmen pulled The driver from her car and drove off with Carroll and her interpreter , all in 15 seconds . her interpreter was found dead . A video showing U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) aired Tuesday . & quot;Brigades of Vengeance&quot ; threatened to kill U.S. journalist Jill Carroll , in Baghdad for The Christian Science Monitor ( CSM ) unless the U. S. freed female prisoners in Iraq within 72 hours . The press and Carroll 's family appealed for her release . US forces raided a mosque , following a tip .

summary: On Jan. 18 , 2005 the Iraqi justice ministry announced that six Iraqi female detainees are to be released soon . U.S. forces had earlier said U.S. forces were holding a total of eight Iraqi women and on Jan. 19 stated that some may be released & quot;in accordance with the normal process,&quot ; but both U.S. and Iraqi spokesmen denied reacting to the kidnappers ' threats . Sen. John Kerry announced that Sen. John Kerry had discussions with Iraqi President Talabani on Carroll 's fate and Carroll 's mother read an appeal on CNN for her mother daughter 's release as the 72 - hour deadline approached . On Jan. 19 , new images of Carroll 's surrounded by masked gunmen of the so - called Revenge Brigade were aired . Among those pleading for her daughter 's release were her mother and Iraqi Muslim leaders . A US - based Islamic rights group sent representatives to Baghdad on Carroll 's behalf . Sen. John Kerry discussed Carroll 's plight with Iraqi officials during Sen. John Kerry visit to Iraq . the Iraqi justice ministry announced that six Iraqi female detainees were due to be released within a week based on a review of six Iraqi female detainees cases . Iraqi and US officials deny released would be in response to the kidnappers ' demands . the kidnappers ' have the kidnappers ' threats to kill Carroll 's unless the US freed all female prisoners in Iraq . the Iraqi justice ministry said six Iraqi female detainees would be released within days but denied any link with kidnappers demands . her mother made an impassioned plea for her daughter 's release on behalf of the family . A US - based Islamic rights group was sending representatives to Baghdad seeking the release of Carroll 's . The White House said Carroll 's safe return is a priority . Iraq main Sunni Arab party called for her daughter 's release . Sen. John Kerry said the fate of Carroll 's overshadowed his visit to Iraq . Carroll 's was kidnapped in one of Baghdad most dangerous neighborhoods . Iraq 's main Sunni Arab party and the Council on American - Islamic Relations ( CAIR ) called for her daughter 's release . the Council on American - Islamic Relations ( CAIR ) would send representatives to Baghdad to seek Carroll 's release . the Council on American - Islamic Relations ( CAIR ) would make a public appeal to the kidnappers Thursday in Amman and Friday in Baghdad . The kidnapping of journalists was condemned . New images were aired Thursday in Amman showing Carroll 's surrounded by masked gunmen . Six of eight Iraqi women detainees were to be freed within days following a review of Six of eight Iraqi women detainees cases , but Iraqi and US officials denied a link with the kidnappers ' demands .

summary: The process for electing a pope is governed by centuries - old rules with some modernization introduced in 1996 . New rules on voting provided that the required 2/3 majority of cardinals would revert to a single majority if no decision had been reached after several days . On the morning of April 18 , 2005 , Cardinal Ratzinger , a prominent contender for pope , delivered a homily strongly endorsing orthodoxy . That afternoon , after the first voting session , a signal of white smoke from The Sistine Chapel roof , which would indicate election of a pope , turned to black , showing that no decision had been made . On Sunday , April 17 , 115 Roman Catholic cardinals representing 52 countries and six continents arrived at the Vatican to select a successor to Pope John Paul II . On Monday , 115 Roman Catholic cardinals representing 52 countries and six continents convened a conclave , a secret and sacred gathering , in Sistine Chapel . Following 115 Roman Catholic cardinals representing 52 countries and six continents oath , the selection process began . A two - thirds majority is required to elect a pope . Outside , attention was focused on The Sistine Chapel roof , watching for the white smoke of burning ballots that would indicate a successful election . Monday , black smoke rose from the chimney . 115 Roman Catholic cardinals representing 52 countries and six continents would return twice daily , beginning Tuesday , for additional ballots . The conclave was introduced to inconvenience cardinals and thus speed up The process for electing a pope . Today The conclave helps preserve secrecy . The opening pageant is televised , then all news media and audiovisual or communication equipment is banned . Cardinals move into St. Martha 's House and are forbidden to talk to anyone not sworn to secrecy . In 1996 Pope John Paul II instituted new rules concerning choosing a pope . Until a two - thirds majority is reached the pattern is seven ballots and a day of rest . If a deadlock remains after 12 days , voting may resort to simple majority . Bells will ring when a pope is elected . On April 18 , 2005 , 115 Roman Catholic cardinals representing 52 countries and six continents were sequestered in the Vatican to elect a new pope . After a televised mass , 115 Roman Catholic cardinals representing 52 countries and six continents took the cardinals ' oath , then moved to Sistine Chapel . 115 Roman Catholic cardinals representing 52 countries and six continents meet twice a day , voting twice each session , until one man receives a 2/3 's majority . After each vote the ballots are burned - black smoke signals no one was elected . When a pope is chosen , white smoke will be accompanied by bells . Pilgrims in St. Peter 's Square watched white smoke .

summary: Although many said there was no clear front - runner among the 115 cardinals , Ratzinger 's sermon at the pre - conclave mass put Ratzinger 's in the limelight for conservatives . On April 19th white smoke rising from the chapel roof at 5:15 p.m. stayed white . Ratzinger 's had been chosen after four ballots . Ratzinger 's victory was cheered widely as an extension of the legacy of John Paul II , but questioned by more liberal elements concerned by a sharply divided church . There was hope in Ratzinger 's explanation that Ratzinger 's would be Benedict XVI after Benedict XV who gave himself to & quot;peacemaking , reconciliation and harmony.&quot ; On April 19th , white smoke puffed from the chapel chimney , signaling the election of Ratzinger 's . After four ballots , Roman Catholic cardinals elected Ratzinger 's . Ratzinger 's took the name Pope Benedict XVI . In the 13th century cardinals spent more time hunting and feasting than seriously deliberating , so in 1271 a mob tore the roof off cardinals meeting place , exposing cardinals to the elements , and gave cardinals only bread and water to force a decision . Now cardinals are locked up until cardinals decide . Previously , conclaves were held in the town where the last pope died . Smoke became the logical means of signaling a decision because ballots needed to be burned . After John Paul II death the Vatican stipulated that special chemicals be added to the smoke and bells be rung to avoid confusion . In April 19th , Ratzinger 's was the election of a new pope on the fourth ballot , signaled by the white smoke and tolling bells . Following the election of a new pope , Ratzinger 's accepted and announced the name Pope Benedict XVI . Ratzinger 's was then taken to a dressing chamber nicknamed the & quot;Room of Tears&quot ; , where Ratzinger 's donned the papal vestments . A Chilean cardinal then proclaimed & quot;We have a pope!&quot ; from the central balcony over St. Peter 's Square where thousands of pilgrims were gathering . Ratzinger 's then appeared and made a brief speech . the 115 cardinals were on surrounding balconies .

summary: Betty Friedan was a brilliant , visionary woman who came to prominence in 1963 with publication of Betty Friedan book , The Feminine Mystique . her book , The Feminine Mystique brought about a re - examination of women 's role in society . Betty Friedan found that many women were not content with lives of domesticity , and Betty Friedan campaigned for greater access to work outside the home . Betty Friedan was the first president of the National Organization for Women and a leader in the drive to pass the Equal Rights Amendment . Betty Friedan was abrasive , and some feminists criticized Betty Friedan for ignoring concerns of women of color , lesbians and the poor . In 1963 Betty Friedan wrote her book , The Feminine Mystique . her book , The Feminine Mystique exposed American women 's discontent with domesticity and workplace discrimination . Betty Friedan started an international movement . Betty Friedan founded and was elected president of NOW . Betty Friedan helped found the National Women 's Political Caucus and a group that later became NARAL . For two decades Betty Friedan led demonstrations , protest marches , and news conferences . Betty Friedan moderate belief that women should have equal rights but not at the expense of alienating men caused a split with other feminist leaders and Betty Friedan relegation to the sidelines in the late 1970 's . Betty Friedan 1963 controversial bestseller & quot;The Feminine Mystique&quot ; made Betty Friedan the leading spokeswoman for a revitalized women 's movement . her book , The Feminine Mystique identified the unhappiness of post - WWII American women unfulfilled by traditional domesticity . Betty Friedan was an advocate of the Equal Rights Amendment and pushed for legal abortion . Betty Friedan helped found the National Organization for Women in 1966 and was the National Organization for Women first president , splitting with the National Organization for Women over the National Organization for Women emphasis on lesbian issues and alienating men . Betty Friedan led the 1970 500,000 - person Women 's Strike for Equality . Betty Friedan was a founder of the National Women 's Political Caucus and NARAL . Betty Friedan wrote & quot;The Second Stage&quot ; in 1981 . her book , The Feminine Mystique started a social revolution that led to a revitalized women 's movement . her book , The Feminine Mystique was included in Human Events magazine 's list of the & quot;Ten Most Harmful Books of the 19th and 20th centuries.&quot ; Betty Friedan helped found the National Organization for Women in 1966 and was one of the founders of the National Women 's Political Caucus . In 1970 , Betty Friedan led a 500,000 - person Women 's Strike for Equality down Fifth Avenue . Betty Friedan pushed for equal pay , sex - neutral help - wanted ads , maternity leave , child - care centers for working parents , and other topics considered radical at the time .

summary: The feminist movement split , and Betty Friedan , who helped to start The feminist movement , was sidelined . Betty Friedan , who helped to start it resigned as the first president of the National Organization for Women after only a few years , as other women radicalized The feminist movement . When Betty Friedan , who helped to start it died at age 85 in 2006 , newspapers had to remind readers that before Betty Friedan , who helped to start it and the work of The feminist movement , equal pay for equal work , sex - blind help - wanted ads , the right of pregnant women to keep pregnant women jobs , non - discriminatory admissions standards for professional schools and many other matters were considered not only controversial , but radical proposals . Betty Friedan , who helped to start it helped to empower women to fight for parity with men in the workplace , equal jobs , pay and respect . Betty Friedan , who helped to start it encouraged women to reject the & quot;contented homemaker&quot ; role and demand fuller participation in life . Some considered Betty Friedan , who helped to start it the most influential woman of the second millennium . Betty Friedan , who helped to start it raised issues such as paid maternity leave , affordable childcare , job training for women and reproductive self determination , which were radical in the 1960 's but are still important today . Some feminists felt Betty Friedan , who helped to start it focused too much on the concerns of white middle class married women instead of all women . Betty Friedan , who helped to start it first cause was unification of help - wanted ads separated by gender . Betty Friedan , who helped to start it empowered women to fight for parity with men . Betty Friedan , who helped to start it started a revolution , getting women organized and demanding change . Drawing on Betty Friedan , who helped to start it own unhappy Midwestern childhood , Betty Friedan , who helped to start it voiced the dissatisfaction suburban wives struggled with alone . Betty Friedan , who helped to start it made the point that if an entire group has a problem , the solution ca n't be purely personal . Betty Friedan , who helped to start it compared housewives resigned to housewives resigned to their situation situation to inmates in comfortable concentration camps . Betty Friedan , who helped to start it was a moderate in the women 's rights movement , believing women should have equal rights but not at the expense of alienating men . Betty Friedan , who helped to start it & quot;The Feminine Mystique&quot ; triggered profound changes in American life , changes so basic that most people today find it hard to believe that when Betty Friedan 's & quot;The Feminine Mystique&quot ; was published a woman 's role was to get married , raise children , keep a clean house , and please a woman 's husband ; the only careers & quot;acceptable&quot ; for women were nursing and teaching ; and girls did not compete in sports . The entry of women into the workforce permanently changed the culture and economy , not only in America , but around the world .

summary: News of Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement dominated the airways . People generally accepted Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement but had strong reservations about Camilla Parker Bowles ' becoming & quot;Queen Camilla.&quot ; Prince Charles ' senior advisors said Prince Charles ' must choose between marrying or banishing Prince Charles ' long - term partner . Camilla Parker Bowles ' agreed to Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement , but only to present the Brits with the conventional lifestyle required before Prince Charles ' could become King . Chinese soothsayers predicted a long and happy marriage for Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' . Chinese soothsayers determined that the wedding date would be auspicious based on Prince Charles ' Chinese zodiac sign . Prince Charles ' was advised Prince Charles ' needed to choose between marrying or banishing Camilla Parker Bowles ' before Prince Charles ' could become King . Tony Blair gave Camilla Parker Bowles ' legal advice before Camilla Parker Bowles ' approved Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement . The House of Commons burst into cheers at News of Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement . Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' decided Camilla Parker Bowles ' would not be queen . There was no legal impediment to queen . The Archbishop 's approval and participation could help allay concerns about a divorced Charles being supreme governor of the Church of England . Camilla Parker Bowles ' divorced Andrew Parker Bowles in 1995 . The Australian Republican Movement saw a surge of new memberships after News of Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement . Praise for Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement continues . The House of Commons reportedly cheered . The British media praised the plans . The London Times reported that Prince Charles ' had been advised to marry or discontinue Prince Charles ' affair . A Friday poll in the Daily Telegraph had 65 % for Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement and 24 % against . Reactions in Australia were mixed , with The Australian Republican Movement gaining more support . The New Zealand Anglican Church welcomed News of Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement . Hong Kong fortune tellers declared that Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement will be a great success . According to The London Times , Prince Charles ' senior advisors told Prince Charles ' that Prince Charles ' must either marry Camilla Parker Bowles ' or banish Camilla Parker Bowles ' from Prince Charles ' life to avoid a constitutional crisis should Prince Charles ' become king . If Prince Charles ' became king , Camilla Parker Bowles ' would have the title of Princess Consort , a vague title that would let Camilla Parker Bowles ' develop Camilla Parker Bowles ' role over time . In Australia a group that wants to sever ties with the British monarchy reported a surge of new members in reaction to News of Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement . The Prime Minister announced that Prince Charles ' and Camilla Parker Bowles ' engagement would not cause Australia to abandon the British monarch as head of state .

summary: In February 2005 , Yusuf Islam said Yusuf Islam had obtained & quot;substantial damages&quot ; against two British newspapers which alleged Yusuf Islam had been involved in terrorism . The dispute was sparked by Yusuf Islam deportation from the U.S. After the 2005 London bombings , Yusuf Islam said the true meaning of Islam should be taught to Muslim children to discourage extremism . Yusuf Islam was founder of the Islamiya Primary School . Yusuf Islam gave a concert in Jakarta to raise cash for tsunami victims of 2005 . Yusuf Islam recorded a new song , & quot;Indian Ocean,&quot ; in response to the disaster and opened an office of Yusuf Islam own charity in Indonesia . Yusuf Islam , will host a concert in Jakarta to raise money for tsunami disaster victims . Yusuf Islam will perform a new song , & quot;Indian Ocean,&quot ; . Proceeds from a new song , & quot;Indian Ocean,&quot ; recording would go to aid tsunami - orphaned children through his own charity . two British newspapers which alleged he had been involved in terrorism paid unspecified damages to Yusuf Islam over articles suggesting Yusuf Islam had links to terrorists . Yusuf Islam said unspecified damages would be given to relief projects in areas hit by the December Indian Ocean tsunami . the U.S. still has not explained why Yusuf Islam name was added to the no - fly list . Yusuf Islam hosted a benefit concert for tsunami relief in Jakarta in January 2005 and recorded a new song , & quot;Indian Ocean,&quot ; to provide aid to tsunami orphaned children . his own charity set up an office in Indonesia to assist tsunami orphaned children . Yusuf Islam said in February 2005 that Yusuf Islam work was adversely affected when two British newspapers which alleged he had been involved in terrorism alleged Yusuf Islam had been involved in terrorism . two British newspapers which alleged he had been involved in terrorism apologized , paid Yusuf Islam legal fees , and promised not to repeat alleged . A year after Yusuf Islam was barred from entering the U.S. , the U.S. had not revealed the U.S. reason for doing so . In early 2005 , Yusuf Islam devoted Yusuf Islam time to helping Indonesian victims of the December Indian Ocean tsunami . Yusuf Islam planned to give a concert , release a record , and donate money from two British newspapers which alleged he had been involved in terrorism . two British newspapers which alleged he had been involved in terrorism paid unspecified damages for October articles suggesting Yusuf Islam had ties to terrorism . In September , Yusuf Islam spoke at the opening of an Islamic study center at Cardiff University . There Yusuf Islam placed some blame for the 2005 London bombings on foreign policy , but also called on Muslim schools to keep students from extremist ideas . In 1995 , Yusuf Islam school in London became the first Islamic school to win public funding .

summary: Michael Jackson was arrested on Nov. 19 , 2003 on ten counts including molestation of a 12 - year - old boy and freed on $ 3million bail . Michael Jackson pleaded not guilty . One of several searches of locations linked to Michael Jackson seized the top layer of a mattress used in Michael Jackson mansion . A DNA swab from Michael Jackson mouth was taken the same day . Jury selection for Michael Jackson trial is scheduled for Jan. 31 , 2005 . During 2004 Michael Jackson asked that the prosecutor be removed , led a protest against rapper Eminem , faced charges of non - payment of bills , and received an e - mail death threat . Michael Jackson woes are many since arrested . Michael Jackson 's suing XtraJet for videotaping Michael Jackson conversations with Michael Jackson lawyer . There 's upheaval in Michael Jackson legal team since Michael Jackson fired two attorneys , hired one , and another took leave . Michael Jackson attorneys accused District Attorney Tom Sneddon of having a vendetta against Michael Jackson . Prosecutors alleged Michael Jackson plotted to kidnap Michael Jackson accuser . In one week , Michael Jackson was hit with two non - payment lawsuits . rapper Eminem video mocked Michael Jackson and angered Michael Jackson , and Michael Jackson received a death threat . Investigators launched another search of Neverland Ranch , which frightened Michael Jackson children , and took a DNA sample . In November 2003 police arrested Michael Jackson on several counts of child molestation after having raided Michael Jackson California ranch . Michael Jackson attorney accused District Attorney Tom Sneddon of having a vendetta against Michael Jackson and alleged in a lawsuit that private conversations used as evidence had been illegally recorded . Michael Jackson had problems with his legal team . rapper Eminem issued A rapper 's video . A former business associate seeking $ 3 million sued for breach of contract and a merchant sued to collect nearly $ 180,000 . In December 2003 investigators searched his California ranch and took DNA from Jackson 's mouth . Michael Jackson is having a rough time . Michael Jackson long - time attorney Steve Cochran left the defense team for unknown reasons . rapper Eminem made A rapper 's video . Michael Jackson has been sued for three million dollars by a former business associate for breach of contract and for $ 180,000 by an antique store for unpaid bills . And a Canadian pleaded guilty to emailing a death threat to Michael Jackson . Another search was made of his California ranch on 3 December and the following day investigators took DNA samples from Jackson 's mouth .

summary: The Michael Jackson trial got underway on Jan. 31 , 2005 . On Feb. 15 jury selection was delayed when Michael Jackson was rushed to the hospital with the flu . Michael Jackson was discharged after 23 hours . On Feb. 28 the presiding judge revealed details of the charges for the first time . The prosecutor in opening arguments stated that Michael Jackson & quot;world was rocked&quot ; in February 2003 by broadcast of a British television documentary & quot;Living With Michael Jackson.&quot ; A friend called the effect & quot;a train wreck,&quot ; and The prosecutor said it resulted in a plot to kidnap the boy . Jury selection for The Michael Jackson trial began on Jan. 31 , 2005 . Michael Jackson could face 20 years in prison . On Feb. 15 , Michael Jackson was hospitalized for 33 hours suffering from the flu , delaying jury selection . By February 23 , jury selection was completed . Opening arguments were delivered on Feb. 28 . Michael Jackson was accused of molesting the boy at Michael Jackson Neverland Ranch between February 3 and March 3 , 2003 . accused alleged Michael Jackson plotted to kidnap the boy and the boy family and hold the boy and his family in order to limit the damage caused by a British television documentary . On Jan. 31 , 2005 began with Jury selection . On Feb. 15 Michael Jackson was rushed to the hospital with the flu , delaying the jury selection in The Michael Jackson trial for 3 - 4 days . Michael Jackson left the hospital after being there 33 hours . On February 23 a jury was selected . After a jury was sworn in , attorneys began the selection of eight alternate jurors . On Feb. 28 the presiding judge revealed the detail of the charges and read the indictment that accused Michael Jackson of molesting the boy at his Neverland Ranch in 2003 . Jury selection for The Michael Jackson trial was delayed on Monday 15 January when Michael Jackson was rushed to the hospital with the flu . Michael Jackson left the hospital Wednesday . The Michael Jackson trial started on Jan. 31 , 2005 and a jury of four men and eight women was selected on 23 February . On the presiding judge read a nine - page indictment detailing the charges of child molestation and conspiracy against Michael Jackson . Michael Jackson was accused of giving the boy alcohol and surfing pornographic websites with Michael Jackson and Michael Jackson brother and of trying to ensure that his family did not publicly denounce Michael Jackson .

summary: The Bush administration began an offensive in 2005 to persuade Congress to renew the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 . the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 gave broad powers to government agencies to obtain information for fighting terrorism . The Bush administration argued the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 has prevented further attacks . A coalition of conservatives and liberals organized to demand changes , believing the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 endangered individual freedom . A coalition of conservatives and liberals challenged provisions giving access to library , medical and firearm - ownership records ; allowing secret searches ; and allowing surveillance of protests . Earlier , a judge disallowed forcing Internet providers to turn over records . the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 included major sections that expire in 2005 if not renewed by Congress . The Bush administration calls for renew , but liberals and some conservatives maintain that the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 gives the federal government too much power . Bush threatens to veto any congressional weakening of the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 . The specific sections are targeted by A coalition of conservatives and liberals . The specific sections are : the one permitting easy access to records in terrorism - related cases ; the provision for & quot;sneak and peek&quot ; secret searches before a warrant is presented ; and an overbroad definition of & quot;terrorists&quot ; that could include non - terrorist suspects . Weeks after 911 Congress passed the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 . the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 expanded Federal law enforcement officials ' surveillance and prosecution power against suspected terrorists . Key elements of the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 were to expire at the end of 2005 . Congress had to decide whether to renew Key elements of the Act . The Bush administration argued that the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 had kept America safe and sought to retain all elements . Opponents argued that the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 undermined freedom and gave the federal government too much power . Groups opposed to the renewal of the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 formed a coalition , Patriots to Restore Checks and Balances , to lobby Congress to repeal key provisions . Bush , the outgoing Attorney General John Ashcroft and the outgoing Attorney General John Ashcroft deputy , James Comfey , have promoted the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 . Bush and incoming Attorney General Gonzales have called for the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 extension . the outgoing Attorney General John Ashcroft speeches promoting of the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 have not violated anti - lobbying rules . The liberal American Civil Liberties Union and conservative libertarian groups have joined forces to oppose giving government access to library and medical records . a judge ruled that a provision of the Patriot Act , parts of which would expire in 2006 that enabled federal authorities to force Internet service providers to provide subscriber information violated the First and Fourth Amendments .

summary: By April 2005 five states were in revolt against the Patriot Act , urging that restrictions be placed on the Patriot Act broad powers . The & quot;library provision&quot ; that allowed searching of library records , caused five states and 375 communities in 43 states to pass anti - the Patriot Act resolutions , the ACLU said . Nevertheless , the Bush administration continued the Bush administration campaign to preserve the Patriot Act and even to expand the Patriot Act . Congress considered legislation that could enlarge the FBI 's ability to wiretap people whom the FBI 's suspected were security risks . Also , legislation that could enlarge the FBI 's ability to wiretap people whom it suspected were security risks would lift a restriction on special warrants , that information obtained must be related to terrorism . Congress began consideration of the Patriot Act renewal on April 4 , 2005 . By then five states and 375 communities in 43 states had passed resolutions warning of the Patriot Act excesses . Senators Craig ( R - ID ) and Durbin ( D - IL ) had drafted The Safety and Freedom Enforcement Act ( SAFE ) eliminating the three main targets of the civil libertarians . the Bush administration pushed for making the Patriot Act permanent . Testimony by the Attorney General and the FBI 's Director opened the debate . By June the Bush administration case was made in draft legislation offered by Sen. Roberts ( R - KS ) further strengthening federal powers and countering The Safety and Freedom Enforcement Act ( SAFE ) . Anti - the Patriot Act resolutions were adopted in five states and 375 communities . While Congress debated making the Patriot Act provisions permanent , there was strong bipartisan support for retaining the & quot;sunset&quot ; provisions to ensure Justice Department accountability . Critics of the Patriot Act sought changes to limit the Patriot Act in several ways , including informing suspects of & quot;sneak and peek&quot ; searches within 7 days unless a judge intervened . The Senate Intelligence Committee met behind closed doors to consider a draft bill that would escalate government police powers . a draft bill that would escalate government police powers was viewed as a Republican maneuver to shift arguments to expanding the Patriot Act . Delayed Notification Searches ( called sneak and peek ) are the central issue regarding extending , modifying or curbing executive powers under the Patriot Act . Justice Department urges extension . the ACLU and some conservative libertarians call for curbing powers . Five state legislatures and several communities have passed resolutions to limit executive powers . A bill by Senators Craig ( R - ID ) and Durbin ( D - IL ) would amend the Patriot Act . A draft bill by The Senate Intelligence Committee would extend the FBI 's powers . Gonzales said at one point the Patriot Act had been used 35 times . Later , 35 times was given as 155 times as of January 2005 .

summary: The so - called Real ID Act was attached to a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill . Consequently , legislators had little time to debate a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill before passing a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill . Only driver 's licenses from complying states will be valid for air travel and other official identification purposes . The so - called Real ID Act would deny licenses to illegal immigrants and would significantly raise the standard of proof of persecution for asylum - seekers . Proponents expect greater homeland security . Opponents say The so - called Real ID Act is anti - immigrant and would add cost and delays to DMV processes . Civil libertarians argue The so - called Real ID Act creates a de facto national ID card and threatens individual privacy . The so - called Real ID Act was attached to a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill , bypassing hearings and debate . The so - called Real ID Act contains provisions aimed at keeping terrorists from crossing US borders . The most controversial would make it hard for states to issue driver 's licenses to illegal immigrants and possibly require a national ID card . States would need to add security features to driver 's licenses and create license databases . Most Americans detested the idea . The ACLU tried to stop a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill . Opponents viewed a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill as a blatant attack on immigrants ' rights and did not believe a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill would improve US security . House Judiciary Committee Sensenbrenner attached House Judiciary Committee Sensenbrenner Real ID Act to a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill . a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill would make it more difficult for states to issue driver 's licenses to illegal immigrants and that a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill would protect against terrorist entry into the US . Civil libertarians oppose a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill on grounds that a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill would create a de facto national ID card . a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill may run counter to the president 's support for a temporary guest worker program . States fear The so - called Real ID Act would add another unfunded federal mandate on States and create delays at motor vehicle bureaus . Immigrant rights groups oppose The so - called Real ID Act . The so - called Real ID Act was attached to a must - pass Iraq appropriations bill without legislative review . The so - called Real ID Act is intended to stop illegal aliens from having driver 's licenses to use to board airplanes and enter public buildings , raise the standard of proof of persecution for asylum seekers , and build a fence on the border near Tijuana , Mexico . Opponents fear The so - called Real ID Act will create a national ID card ; impinge on states ' powers ; give untrained workers responsibility for immigration control ; gridlock the license process ; increase unlicensed , uninsured drivers ; deny qualified asylum seekers ; harm the environment ; and cost five times what is expected .

summary: Mexico 's president condemned the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border . Homeland Security waived environmental laws , as the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border allows , and authorized completion of the border fence . States are finding the financial , logistical and technical demands of the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border daunting . A possible unintended effect might be increased unlicensed , uninsured motorists . California opted to offer illegal immigrants separate licenses for driving only , not to be used as official identification . By broadening the definition of terrorist groups , the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border has complicated the laws regarding refugees resettling in the US . the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border required that in three years states determine whether driver 's license applicants are in the US legally . Civil libertarians and immigration rights activists protested the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border . States blasted the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border because the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border placed a large burden on States and worker training requirements . States believed the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border grossly underestimated financial , logistical and technological demands . Some states need to amend Some states laws and others need to overhaul others computing systems to verify the accuracy of documents . the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border is expected to be phased in over a 5 - year period , beginning in 2008 . the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border restricts asylum , bans drivers ' licenses for illegal aliens and allows for construction of a wall along the Mexican border near San Diego which may cause harm to the Tijuana estuary . Vicente Fox has condemned the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border . An editorial claims that denying licenses to undocumented workers will result in fewer licensed and insured drivers and thus less safety . the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border has some requirements that would necessitate extensive and costly changes to systems used by some states . California is considering a license valid only for driving and not as i d for other purposes . the Real ID Act , including provisions for the construction of a wall along the common border became law in May. Governors and motor vehicles officials protested the driver 's license portion , citing the driver 's license portion impact on Governors and motor vehicles officials budgets and procedures , as well as the resulting requirements to upgrade computer systems and hire and train employees . California began struggling with issuing unique licenses for illegals . the border fence will have severe ecological results . Tens of thousands of refugees were stranded by the act , which denies entry to anyone who helped or was forced to help groups rebelling against even authoritarian regimes .

summary: Merck & amp ; Co. withdrew Merck & amp ; Co. arthritis drug Vioxx from the market in 2004 after a trial showed its arthritis drug Vioxx increased heart attacks and strokes . Merck & amp ; Co. net income plunged 29 % after withdrew . The European Medicines Agency and the US Food and Drug Administration announced The European Medicines Agency and the US Food and Drug Administration would review all COX-2 inhibitors to see if there was a class effect . Hundreds , possibly thousands of lawsuits were likely to be filed against Merck & amp ; Co. , lawyers said , including many class action lawsuits , all claiming injury from taking its arthritis drug Vioxx . Plaintiffs ' cases were strengthened when proof was uncovered that Merck & amp ; Co. knew about its arthritis drug Vioxx risk but discounted Vioxx 's risk . Merck & amp ; Co. withdrew its arthritis drug Vioxx when a trial showed its arthritis drug Vioxx increased the risk of strokes and heart attacks . An the US Food and Drug Administration study estimates its arthritis drug Vioxx may have caused 27,785 attacks / deaths since its arthritis drug Vioxx approval . The medical community was concerned about use of related drug use and sought more guidance . Lawyers estimated thousands of lawsuits would be filed against Merck & amp ; Co. . One settlement estimate was $ 12 billion . Merck & amp ; Co. costs to withdrew its arthritis drug Vioxx from the market were $ 552.6 million and Merck & amp ; Co. profits for the third quarter of 2004 dropped 29 percent . Several medical reports criticized Merck & amp ; Co. failing to stop its arthritis drug Vioxx when data first showed Vioxx 's risk . Merck & amp ; Co. has recalled its arthritis drug Vioxx . Use of its arthritis drug Vioxx may increase risk of stroke and heart attack . recalled is the largest prescription drug recall in history and could lead to an onslaught of lawsuits . its arthritis drug Vioxx is used by 1.3 million Americans and 700,000 in other countries and accounts for sales of $ 2.5B. Class action lawsuits have been filed in Canadian Provinces . Hundreds of plaintiffs lawyers expected to meet in Las Vegas to plan class action strategy . the US Food and Drug Administration estimates its arthritis drug Vioxx could have caused more than 27,000 heart attacks . Merck & amp ; Co. income has dropped 29 % . The European Medicines Agency and the US Food and Drug Administration vowed to review drugs in the same class as its arthritis drug Vioxx . the US Food and Drug Administration said over 27,000 deaths could be attributed to its arthritis drug Vioxx . Lancet concluded The European Medicines Agency and the US Food and Drug Administration should have withdrawn its arthritis drug Vioxx . Many new individual and class action its arthritis drug Vioxx lawsuits were filed in the US and Canada , representing patients , Merck & amp ; Co. shareholders , and former employees with company retirement plans . Radio ads sought plaintiffs for class action suits . Merck & amp ; Co. requested that one judge handle class action suits . Plaintiffs ' lawyers planned to meet in Las Vegas to lay groundwork . Merck & amp ; Co. share price and earnings were reduced .

summary: In November , 2004 , government and expert witnesses told a Senate committee that Federal regulators and Merck & amp ; Co. were aware of risks that Vioxx could cause serious heart problems before Vioxx was approved in 1999 . In Congress , an FDA expert accused FDA of having pressed an FDA expert to withhold results of a study showing dangers posed by Vioxx . The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department began investigations of FDA handling of Vioxx . A study by FDA estimated that Vioxx could have caused 27,785 heart attacks or deaths since Vioxx approval in 1999 . The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department studied Merck 's handling of the drug . FDA was unsure whether FDA insurance would be adequate against lawsuits . Moody 's dropped FDA credit rating because of litigation exposure . A clinical trial of Celebrex , a drug similar to Vioxx , was shut down when researchers found increased risk of heart disease and stroke a Senate committee heard testimony that FDA and FDA were aware of risks that Vioxx could cause serious heart problems before Vioxx was approved . FDA adopted a plan to protect 230 of FDA top executives in case financial trouble necessitated a takeover . FDA disputed the British weekly , Lancet , that Vioxx should have been recalled four years earlier . FDA is the subject of a the Justice Department criminal investigation and an The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission inquiry . FDA shares slumped on that news . The New York state pension fund filed a lawsuit against FDA . Nearly a year before FDA received results of the clinical trial prompting recall of Vioxx , patient records indicated Vioxx posed a cardiovascular risk . an FDA expert accused FDA of pressing an FDA expert to withhold a study showing dangers posed by Vioxx . FDA has adopted large severance packages for executives . Regulators and FDA were accused of knowing Vioxx risks pre - approval . An FDA drug reviewer claimed superiors pressed An FDA drug reviewer to withhold study results showing Vioxx risks . FDA confirmed seeing results showing risk one year before Vioxx was pulled . The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department instituted civil and criminal investigations into Merck 's handling of the drug . State attorneys general criticized FDA return and refund program . The New York state pension fund lost $ 171 million and filed suit against FDA for misleading shareholders . FDA was criticized for offering 230 executives large severance packages . A Celebrex , a drug similar to Vioxx , clinical trial was halted after researchers found risks similar to Vioxx .

summary: In June 2005 , Steve Jobs announced that Apple would switch to Intel chips for some of Apple Macintosh computers in 2006 , all by 2007 . IBM , Apple supplier for 14 years , was unable to deliver IBM , its supplier for 14 years , new PC chip that promised more power and less heat , both needed for laptops Apple planned . switch was a gamble for Apple because software developers would have to re - engineer all programs for Intel chips . Intel celebrated switch , although Macintosh held only 2 % of the market . IBM , its supplier for 14 years , was not badly hurt ; IBM , its supplier for 14 years , had long planned to concentrate on chips for computer games . Steve Jobs is preparing to abandon Apple 14 - year commitment to chips developed by IBM , its supplier for 14 years , and Motorola in favor of Intel processors . Apple has been frustrated by IBM , its supplier for 14 years , failure to deliver a G5 chip that does not generate much heat . After weeks of rumors , Steve Jobs announced that switch would be made by 2007 . Apple must now persuade software developers to make software developers programs run on Intel chips . Apple operating system is viewed as more stable and secure than Windows . Intel CEO said Intel 's CEO company is thrilled to have Apple as a customer . Steve Jobs told software engineers at Apple annual developer conference in San Francisco that Apple will discontinue using IBM and Motorola chips in favor of Intel microprocessors . Apple engineers have secretly worked on switch for five years . Every edition of Macintosh since then has been designed to run on both IBM , its supplier for 14 years , and Intel chips . Apple is producing Developer Transition Kits that will allow software developers to prepare applications to run on both IBM and Intel chips . Apple lower - end computers , like the Mac Mini , will get Intel chips in June 2006 . Apple entire computer line will have Intel chips by December 2007 . On 6 June Apple announced plans to abandon Apple 14 - year ties with IBM and Motorola in favor of Intel processors . Apple had been frustrated by IBM , its supplier for 14 years , inability to develop a chip that could process large amounts of data without overheating . Apple programs will have to be rewritten to run on an Intel - powered Mac , although engineers have already developed codes to ease switch . Apple could lose sales in the short term , as people wait for switch . The first Intel - powered Macs are scheduled for June 2006 ; The first Intel - powered Macs should be switch by the end of 2007 .

summary: Apple rolled out Apple new Intel - based Mac computer in January 2006 , six months early . An Intel - based laptop was to go on sale in February . An Intel - based processor inside a Macintosh put a whole library of Windows - based games and software within the reach of Mac users . Though there were benefits , skeptics questioned Apple move ; in the past , major transactions have lost customers and software developers . Apple helped launch a consortium designed to create new standards to improve the flow of content between TVs , computers and other devices . Speculation is that Apple plans to introduce a Mac Mini computer home entertainment hub . Steve Jobs admitted that Apple had been working on Apple 's move for at least five years , creating two versions of Intel - based Mac one with the current chips and another by Intel - based . Steve Jobs said that Macs would top 3 gigahertz speed by summer . The Apple faithful had been caught by surprise by Apple 's move . The new Intel - based chips that Mac will use is called Core Duo that features two computing engines on a single piece of silicon . its new Intel - based Mac computer will be up to two times faster than the older ones using the G5 chip . In looking for alternative chips , Steve Jobs talked with Sony but was disappointed with Sony design . Adobe Systems and Microsoft vowed to support Macs running existing and new hardware . Apple and Intel - based helped launch a tech consortium to create new standards to improve content flow between devices . Six months ahead of schedule , Apple introduced the new iMac , twice as fast as before but the same price ; and MacBook Pro , four times faster than PowerBook laptops . the new iMac , twice as fast as before but the same price ; and MacBook Pro , four times faster than PowerBook laptops use The new Intel chips that Mac will use . The entire line of Macs will shift to Intel - based by the end of 2006 . On 10 January , six months ahead of schedule , Apple introduced two new Intel - based computers , its new Intel - based Mac computer and a laptop called the MacBook Pro . its new Intel - based Mac computer is two to three times faster than the older ones using the G5 chip , while a laptop called the MacBook Pro is four to five times faster , although two new Intel - based computers , an iMac and a laptop called the MacBook Pro cost the same as the older ones using the G5 chip . Software developers are working on programs that will run on both the Intel - based and the older ones using the G5 chip . Although the processors inside are the same as those used on Windows - based PCs , its new Intel - based Mac computer will not be able to run Windows software .

summary: Steve Fossett 's attempt at the first around - the - world non - stop no - refueling solo flight began with takeoff of the Global Flyer from Salina ( Kansas ) Municipal Airport at 0047GMT on March 1 , 2005 . Steve Fossett 's described takeoff as & quot;difficult&quot ; as the Global Flyer was slower than Steve Fossett 's had expected . By 0400GMT Steve Fossett 's was over Canada where Steve Fossett 's experienced a GPS malfunction , but after a couple of hours the Global Flyer reengaged . At 1607GMT Steve Fossett 's was over Morocco and by 0330GMT March 2nd the Global Flyer was over the Arabian Sea heading east towards Karachi , Pakistan at about 390 mph . Steve Fossett 's left Monday evening from Salina ( Kansas ) Municipal Airport on the first around - the - world non - stop no - refueling solo flight . Steve Fossett 's estimated flying time at 60 - 80 hours . Steve Fossett 's took off at 6:47 and was concerned for a brief moment when the Global Flyer seemed to lose altitude seconds after taking off . By 10 PM Steve Fossett 's approached Canadian airspace and soared toward the Atlantic Ocean . While flying across Canada where he experienced a GPS malfunction Steve Fossett 's GPS a GPS malfunction . After a couple of hours Fossett 's GPS corrected Fossett 's GPS . Monitoring fuel usage was a critical challenge during the first around - the - world non - stop no - refueling solo flight . Steve Fossett 's flew over Africa and the Middle East on Tuesday . Steve Fossett 's , hopes to become the first person to fly solo , non - stop flight around the - world without refueling . the Global Flyer , was designed by Burt Rutan and the first around - the - world non - stop no - refueling solo flight is funded by Richard Branson 's Virgin Atlantic Airways . Departure depends on favorable weather . the Global Flyer does not carry enough fuel for the first around - the - world non - stop no - refueling solo flight without tail winds . the first around - the - world non - stop no - refueling solo flight will begin and terminate at Salina ( Kansas ) Municipal Airport . Steve Fossett 's hopes to make the first around - the - world non - stop no - refueling solo flight in under 80 hours . the first around - the - world non - stop no - refueling solo flight began at 6:47 PM on March 1 , 2005 . By late Tuesday after overcoming a navigational equipment problem , Steve Fossett 's was approaching Pakistan . Steve Fossett 's and the Global Flyer arrived in Salina ( Kansas ) Municipal Airport , on January 7 , 2005 , to prepare for the first around - the - world non - stop no - refueling solo flight . Steve Fossett 's finally took off at 0047 GMT on Tuesday , March 1 . By 0400 , Steve Fossett 's was approaching Canadian air space after flying over Chicago and Detroit . Steve Fossett 's then flew over Canada where he experienced a GPS malfunction and the Atlantic Ocean and was over Morocco at 1607 . After flying over Africa , Steve Fossett 's was over the Arabian Sea , approaching Karachi , Pakistan , at 0330 on Wednesday .

summary: At 0400GMT March 2 over India a reading showed that just 9600 lbs . of fuel remained of the 19,000 lbs at takeoff . Mission control reported a fuel shortage : 2600 lbs . less than Mission control had figured . Fossett decided to press on to Hawaii admitting the fuel problem was & quot;a huge setback.&quot ; Before reaching Hawaii Fossett announced that Fossett would continue on to Salina . By 0930GMT March 3 Global Flyer was southwest of California and that afternoon , after 67 hours in flight , Fossett glided into a perfect landing to the cheers of all of Salina and much of the world . On Wednesday after nearly 29 flight hours Fossett reached Fossett halfway point over India . While relying on autopilot , Fossett could not ignore the complex demands of Global Flyer for more than 10 - 20 minutes at a time . On Wednesday , while flying over mainland China mission control officials reported Fossett fuel was 450 gallons less than expected . Fossett decided to fly to Hawaii to re - evaluate the situation . There Fossett decided to proceed . The jet stream and great tailwinds over the Pacific allowed Fossett to make up time . Fossett made a perfect landing in Salina after a 67 - hour flight . Fossett reached his halfway point over India while flying over India and Fossett also picked up a 100 MPH jet stream boost . While Fossett was over mainland China , mission control officials concluded that Fossett had less fuel than mission control officials had counted on . Despite concluded , Fossett decided to press on to Hawaii . On the final legs of a 67 - hour flight , Fossett stayed awake by drinking a dozen chocolate protein milkshakes . Slightly over 67 hours after departure from Salina , Fossett landed Global Flyer on the same airstrip from which Fossett had departed . Global Flyer had enough fuel remaining to fly another 10 hours . Fossett continued a 67 - hour flight , reaching the half - way point over Myanmar at 0705 GMT on Wednesday . Over mainland China there was concern about the fuel supply , but Fossett decided to continue to Hawaii and at 2000 was east of Japan . As Fossett was north of Hawaii , Fossett again decided to continue because The jet stream was so strong . By 0930 on Thursday , Fossett was 1,151 miles southwest of California . Fossett landed at Salina , at 1948 GMT . Fossett had taken just over 67 hours to fly a 23,000 mile zigzag course around the world .

summary: Peter Jennings 's announcement April 5 , 2005 , that Peter Jennings 's had lung cancer left Peter Jennings 's colleagues at ABC News saddened and dismayed . Peter Jennings 's had been & quot;World News Tonight&quot ; anchorman since 1983 . By the end of the week , ABC News had received 3,400 e - mails offering Peter Jennings 's prayers and good wishes . Peter Jennings 's had not been well for some time and was unable to travel abroad to cover foreign events . However , Peter Jennings 's announcement April 5 , 2005 , that he had lung cancer came as a surprise to Peter Jennings 's . ABC News announced that Peter Jennings 's would continue to anchor the news during chemotherapy treatment , but Peter Jennings 's was unable to do so . ABC News announced on April 5 , 2005 that ABC News anchor on Peter Jennings 's , has lung cancer . Peter Jennings 's , had earlier missed overseas assignments , but was thought to be battling flu . Specialists suggested that lung cancer is in an advanced stage . By the end of the week ABC News had received more than 3,400 e - mails offering Peter Jennings 's prayers and good wishes . On April 29 a statement from Peter Jennings 's was read on & quot;World News Tonight&quot ; thanking Peter Jennings 's good wishers who Peter Jennings 's said & quot;have spoiled Peter Jennings 's rotten&quot ; . ABC News announced that Peter Jennings 's has lung cancer . While making Peter Jennings 's condition public , ABC News did not provide details about the diagnosis or prognosis . Peter Jennings 's , will undergo chemotherapy in New York . Peter Jennings 's will continue to work on the news to the extent Peter Jennings 's can do so comfortably . Peter Jennings 's wrote to Peter Jennings 's staff : & quot;There will be good days and bad&quot ; . Peter Jennings 's had been a heavy smoker until the mid- to late 1980s . Peter Jennings 's returned to regular smoking after the terrorist attacks in 2001 but later quit again . Peter Jennings 's hoarsely announced Peter Jennings 's had lung cancer on April 5 , 2005 and would begin outpatient chemotherapy in New York . A former heavy smoker , he had had health problems since late 2004 . Medical experts speculated , since Peter Jennings 's was not having surgery , that lung cancer was advanced or of the small - cell type . Americans responded with sympathy . Other cancer victims considered Peter Jennings 's a role model . Although Peter Jennings 's had hoped to continue working , Peter Jennings 's went on a leave - of - absence in late April . The last of the & quot;old time&quot ; announcers , Peter Jennings 's illness stunned viewers and leaves ABC News scrambling to find fill - ins and perhaps a replacement .

summary: In January 2005 , Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , former top executives of Tyco International Ltd. , went on trial in New York a second time for stealing $ 600 million from Tyco International Ltd. . The first trial ended in a hung jury . Prosecutors claim Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , former top executives of Tyco International Ltd. , illegally awarded Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , former top executives of Tyco International Ltd. , millions of dollars in bonuses and concealed millions of dollars in bonuses from Tyco International Ltd. board and shareholders . A judge refused to combine a retrial of larceny charges against Dennis Koslowski with charges Dennis Koslowski failed to pay sales taxes on $ 13 million worth of art . If convicted , Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz each could face 25 years in prison . The first trial ended in mistrial . Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , former top executives of Tyco International Ltd. , retrial began January 18 . Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , former top executives of Tyco International Ltd. , allegedly stole $ 600 million from Tyco International Ltd. in unauthorized compensation and the sale of inflated Tyco International Ltd. stock . Dennis Koslowski could face 30 years in prison . Prosecutors are focusing less on Dennis Koslowski life of excess and more on how Dennis Koslowski allegedly looted Tyco International Ltd. . In opening arguments , the defense suggested unauthorized compensation was legitimate , and company directors might be practicing revisionist history . Dennis Koslowski still faces separate tax , conspiracy , falsifying business records and evidence tampering charges . Dennis Koslowski has been charged in a tax case with conspiracy , falsifying business records and tampering with evidence . Dennis Koslowski is accused of scheming with dealers to avoid paying over $ 1 M tax on $ 13 million worth of art . Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , are also accused in a larceny case of looting over $ 600 M from Tyco International Ltd. by illegally awarding He and another Tyco executive , Mark Swartz , bonuses and concealing themselves bonuses from shareholders . A trial of Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , former top executives of Tyco International Ltd. , ended in a hung jury . Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , former top executives of Tyco International Ltd. , are to be retried in New York . A judge refused separate trials . The first unfocused , lengthy trial of Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , former top executives of Tyco International Ltd. , for stealing $ 600 million from Tyco International Ltd. was aborted after juror intimidation . A judge ruled a claim on behalf of Tyco International Ltd. was barred under Bermuda law , but allowed a class action lawsuit by Tyco International Ltd. shareholders . A judge refused to separate Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , former top executives of Tyco International Ltd. , cases or allegations of accounting fraud and looting . In Their retrial , prosecutors are concentrating on accusations that Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , former top executives of Tyco International Ltd. , hid unauthorized bonuses , secretly forgave loans to Dennis Koslowski and Mark Swartz , former top executives of Tyco International Ltd. , , and lied about Tyco International Ltd. finances to inflate stock before selling stock . The defense is trying to discredit the board of directors .

summary: Prosecutors changed tactics in the retrial of Kozlowski and Swartz from accusations of lavish spending used in the first trial , to a focus on charges that Kozlowski and Swartz had awarded Kozlowski and Swartz millions of dollars and concealed it from the board of Tyco . A retired board chairman testified A retired board chairman was never told about millions in forgiven loans and bonuses for Kozlowski and Swartz . Tyco former head of finance testified A retired board chairman never saw that millions of dollars in special bonuses were approved by a compensation committee . Tyco 's former head of finance also said Tyco 's former head of finance was n't aware of any documents to that effect . In Prosecutors case , former Tyco executives were questioned , sometimes for days , about former Tyco executives knowledge or lack thereof about loans forgiven and bonuses paid to Kozlowski . On April 27 , Kozlowski took the stand in Kozlowski defense . Kozlowski denied abusing company loans and bonuses , testifying that A retired board chairman approved company loans and bonuses . Kozlowski did admit to forgetfully omitting $ 25 million bonus that did not appear on Kozlowski 1999 tax return . Cross - examination , which began on April 28 , turned decidedly contentious by the third day . Kozlowski maintained Kozlowski innocence and defended Kozlowski lavish spending throughout . Prosecutors in the first trial say Kozlowski and Swartz stole $ 150 M by improperly forgiving company loans to Kozlowski and Swartz , taking unauthorized bonuses and having Tyco pay personal expenses . In a surprise move , Kozlowski testified in Kozlowski own defense . Kozlowski portrayed Kozlowski as an earnest , often harried , executive who rose through the ranks and had the support of the board of Tyco . Kozlowski could not explain why a $ 25 M bonus did not appear on Kozlowski tax return . Kozlowski finished four days of testimony insisting that Kozlowski left it to lawyers and accountants to decide what to tell shareholders about Kozlowski compensation . A retired board chairman said A retired board chairman was never told about millions in forgiven loans and bonuses for the two executives . Tyco 's former head of finance said A retired board chairman was unaware of compensation committee approval for millions in forgiven loans and bonuses for the two executives . Kozlowski took the stand in the retrial of Kozlowski and Swartz . Kozlowski said A retired board chairman had approved millions in forgiven loans and bonuses for the two executives . Kozlowski thought a $ 20 million fee Kozlowski paid a board member for arranging an acquisition did not require board authorization . Not including forgiven debt on Kozlowski tax form was an oversight . Kozlowski assistant decided to use Tyco loan money for certain payments but Kozlowski conceded Kozlowski responsibility .

summary: Tropical storm Rita appeared likely to be upgraded to a Category 1 hurricane before passing the Florida Keys . Florida Governor declared a state of emergency enabling Florida Governor to oversee evacuations and activate the National Guard . The US National Hurricane Center warned that Tropical storm Rita could threaten Texas and Louisiana within days . Louisiana Governor declared a state of emergency . New Orleans worked to bolster weakened levees and establish a military hospital . Tropical storm Rita was upgraded to Category 2 and expected to reach Category 3 in the Gulf . Along the the Gulf coast refugees were relocated , schools and offices were closed and evacuations were mandated . An evacuation order was issued Monday for the Florida Keys as Tropical storm Rita approached and is likely to be upgraded to a level one hurricane . Tropical storm Rita brushed past Key West Tuesday and was forecast to strengthen to a major hurricane , possibly a category 4 , later in the week . Once again , New Orleans implemented emergency services and some individuals were evacuated . Hurricane Katrina survivors taking refuge in Texas were being uprooted again as Tropical storm Rita threatened . Texas now bears the greatest threat from Tropical storm Rita . The Texas coastal county of Galveston will order a mandatory evacuation on Wednesday in preparation of Tropical storm Rita . Monday , Tropical storm Rita became a Category 1 hurricane . Tuesday Tropical storm Rita increased to a Cat2 and a Cat3 or 4 was feared . Florida declared a state of emergency and residents of the Florida Keys began evacuating . Those remaining were advised to hunker down . In New Orleans , levee system repairs were underway , buses were on stand - by , a military hospital was established , and evacuations began . Hurricane Katrina refugees in Texas were being moved out of state . A mandatory evacuation on Wednesday of The Texas coastal county of Galveston , was ordered and shelters set up . Madrid to Miami flights were suspended and crude futures rose . OPEC promised additional crude if needed . As Tropical storm Rita moved toward the Florida Keys on Sunday 18 September , Florida Governor declared a state of emergency . Monday , residents and tourists were told to evacuate the Florida Keys . By early Tuesday afternoon , Tropical storm Rita had strengthened to a category two storm , with winds of 100 mph and was expected to gain further strength and reach a category three as Tropical storm Rita hit the Gulf waters . Residents of New Orleans were evacuating and Florida Governor declared a state of emergency in western Louisiana . Galveston was expected to order a mandatory evacuation on Wednesday 21 September .
