summary: A judge acquitted two Indian - Born Canadian Sikhs charged with bombing an Air India jumbo jet , killing 329 people . The unexpected end , after 19 months of a trial that cost $ 80 million dollars , left the worst case of mass murder in Canadian history an unsettled mystery . A judge , said A judge did not believe the testimony of witnesses who linked two Indian - Born Canadian Sikhs charged with bombing an Air India jumbo jet , killing 329 people to bombing . The evidence had fallen & quot;markedly short&quot ; of the standard required to convict two Indian - Born Canadian Sikhs charged with bombing an Air India jumbo jet , killing 329 people . Families of passengers who perished proclaimed a & quot;mockery of justice&quot ; and demanded a government investigation . In March 2005 A judge acquitted two Indian - Born Canadian Sikhs charged with bombing an Air India jumbo jet , killing 329 people on eight counts of murder and conspiracy because the government had failed to make a conclusive case . Plane crash victims ' families were devastated and demanded a public inquiry . The Canadian Deputy Prime Minister could see no benefit to calling a public inquiry . The Canadian Police were disappointed at the call . Prosecutors sought grounds to appeal A judge ruling . Canada 's newspapers were shocked at acquitted and the Toronto - based Globe and Mail devoted the Toronto - based Globe and Mail front page to the headline & quot;innocent&quot ; and the names of 329 people . A judge has acquitted two Indian - Born Canadian Sikhs charged with bombing an Air India jumbo jet , killing 329 people ending a trial that cost $ 80 million dollars . A judge said that despite the horrific nature of the alleged crimes , there could be no lowering the standard of proof and that the assortment of prosecution witnesses lacked credibility . acquitted devastated family members of 329 people . Shocked prosecutors must ponder whether there is ground for appeal and defend Shocked prosecutors decision to bring the case to court . The feasibility of an appeal is in question because of strong wording of Josephson 's ruling . the case remains open . On 16 March , A judge acquitted two Indian - Born Canadian Sikhs charged with bombing an Air India jumbo jet , killing 329 people . Saying that Prosecutors major witnesses were not credible , A judge stated that Prosecutors had failed to prove two Indian - Born Canadian Sikhs charged with bombing an Air India jumbo jet , killing 329 people guilty beyond a reasonable doubt but added that A judge was certain both bombs had originated on flights out of Vancouver . A judge had heard the case without a jury at two Indian - Born Canadian Sikhs charged with bombing an Air India jumbo jet , killing 329 people request . two Indian - Born Canadian Sikhs charged with bombing an Air India jumbo jet , killing 329 people were released immediately . acquitted shocked everyone . Many people sharply criticized the police and secret services and demanded a government investigation .

summary: Roper vs. Simmons presented the Supreme Court a chance to strike down the death penalty for crimes committed by 16 - 17 - year - olds . Justices Stevens , Souter , Ginsburg and Breyer were expected to vote against the death penalty for crimes committed by 16 - 17 - year - olds while Chief Justice Rehnquist and Justices Scalia and Thomas would be for the death penalty for crimes committed by 16 - 17 - year - olds . Justices Kennedy and O'Connor appeared to be & quot;swing votes.&quot ; In the initial hearing Kennedy expressed concerns about exempting 16 - 17 - year - olds but also noted that & quot;world opinion is against us&quot ; in executing juveniles . O'Connor noted that several states had already raised the minimum age for execution to 18 . On October 13 , 2004 , the Supreme Court struggled over the legality of the death penalty for crimes committed by 16 - 17 - year - olds in Roper vs. Simmons . Simmons attorney argued that a national consensus has emerged that the death penalty for crimes committed by 16 - 17 - year - olds is cruel and unusual punishment . Simmons ' attorney compared Roper vs. Simmons to the 2002 case in which the Supreme Court abolished the death penalty for mentally retarded offenders . Simmons ' attorney argued that the Supreme Court should uphold the execution of minors because some crimes are so heinous as to warrant the execution of minors . Justices Kennedy 's and Day O'Connor 's votes are likely to be pivotal . the Supreme Court heard arguments on Roper vs. Simmons on October 13 , 2004 . the Supreme Court decision will determine whether the death penalty for crimes committed by 16 - 17 - year - olds can be given for crimes committed by 16 and 17 year olds . the Supreme Court ended the death penalty for those 15 and younger in 1988 and mentally retarded in 2002 . The outcome appears dependent on the votes of Justices Kennedy and O'Connor . Key issues are has the nation 's consensus changed , should world consensus influence US law , and the brain development of these youngsters . Since 1976 , 22 have been executed . Now 73 people are on death row in 12 states . In Roper vs. Simmons the Supreme Court heard arguments challenging the constitutionality of the death penalty for crimes committed by 16 - 17 - year - olds . The defense argued that minors were not fully developed intellectually or morally and that therefore such executions violate the constitution 's ban on cruel and unusual punishment . The defense asserted that a national consensus had emerged on cruel and unusual punishment and pointed out that the nation 's is the only country in the world that allows the execution of juveniles . Prosecutors contended that Simmons was old enough to know right from wrong and challenged the notion that a national consensus had emerged .

summary: On March 1 , 2005 the Supreme Court ruled in a 5 - 4 vote that executing 16 - and 17 - year olds violates the constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment . Justice Kennedy , the decisive & quot;swing vote&quot ; also pointed out in the majority opinion , that the United Stated had been the only remaining nation endorsing the execution of juveniles . Justice Scalia in a dissenting opinion countered that & quot;what the foreign sources ' affirm ' is the justices ' own notion of how the world ought to be.&quot ; ruled commutes death sentences to life in prison for 73 inmates in 13 states . On March 1 , 2005 , the Supreme Court ruled 5 - 4 that the death penalty for murderers who were under age 18 at the time of their crime is unconstitutional . Justice Kennedy , the decisive & quot;swing vote&quot said in the majority opinion that because juveniles still struggle to define juveniles identities it is less supportable to conclude that even a heinous crime is evidence of irretrievably depraved character . Justice Kennedy , the decisive & quot;swing vote&quot noted that the United was the last remaining nation to abolish the death penalty for minors . Justice Kennedy , the decisive & quot;swing vote&quot comment reignited debate over the Supreme Court consideration of foreign laws and opinions when interpreting the Constitution . On March 1 , 2005 , the Supreme Court declared that the death sentence for crimes committed by 16 and 17 year olds was cruel and unusual punishment , thus violating the 8th Amendment . Justice Kennedy , the decisive & quot;swing vote&quot wrote the majority opinion citing the emotional immaturity of teenagers , the changing national consensus , and the weight of international opinion against executing minors . The dissenting opinions disputed the emotional immaturity of teenagers , the changing national consensus , and the weight of international opinion against executing minors . Justice O'Connor voted with the conservatives , Rehnquist , Thomas and Justice Scalia . In Roper v. Simmons the Supreme Court ruled 5 - to-4 that executing 16- and 17 - year - olds violated the constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment . ruled noted that the brains of adolescents function differently from those of adults and observed that American society believes that adulthood begins at 18 in regard to voting , serving on a jury , or marrying without parental consent . ruled also stated that the & quot;national consensus&quot ; on capital punishment had changed and that the United was the only country that allowed the execution of minors , thus confirming the importance of international opinion .
